1.content:
“Man! It is so boring in this town! Why can’t anything interesting ever happen?”

“Careful Chel. You know the old saying, be careful what you wish for.”

“You’re too stuffy Chris. Those old sayings are just outdated hogwash. Nothing but a series of coincidences that created them in the first place.”

I sighed and dropped the subject. I wouldn’t be able to change her mind. I never could. She was too much of what people would call a free spirit. She got a thought in her head and ran with it. Said she wanted to live out her high school life to its fullest. I had forgotten how long I had been here protecting her from the trouble she got into. How long I have secretly loved her. She didn’t see me as a romantic interest and that hurt. She had already rejected me multiple times. But I was just a fool looking for punishment because I still stayed by her side.

I squeezed my fist, staring at it as we walked home from school. I had gotten strong in order to protect her. But it wasn’t enough. It was never enough. There were always stronger people out there. Always those faster than me. I was good, but I wasn’t a god. She didn’t know about all the training I had put my body through, all the fights I had fought for her. She didn’t need to know. She probably wouldn’t care if she did. Probably yell at me for fighting. Because that was just the way she was.

But I would accept her disapproval. Accept the lies I was living for her sake. If it meant I could let her live. If it meant I could keep harm from coming to her. Even if she didn’t love me, I still loved her. I would be her shield and her sword. I would be the buffer between her and the rest of the world. It was the only thing I could do.

I smiled wistfully as she hurried ahead of me to smell some pink flowers like she always did. Her long blond hair trailing behind her like a cloak. Her chest almost bursting out of the school uniform and the edges of her skirt flapping in the wind. I tried to sneak a peak at her panties but of course it never happened just like every other time. It was like some unseen hand was teasing me. Lifting it up so much and then holding it down right before the moment of exposure came. Still, at least I got to appreciate her legs.

“I will speak with you like this while we watch this story of mortals unfold. Conveying extra knowledge and adding my insights for your pleasure. Already I find these two interesting. They are not like other people though I do not know why. They are not gods, and they are not children that I created inhabiting their body. Yet they disrupt the flow of the world. They are a part of it and yet apart from it, creating ripples with their very existence. Most curious. I did not realize this until I focused on them. It was but happenstance that I chose this spot for our little game.”

“Whoops. It seems I have already given away a hint by admitting neither one of these two are gods, therefore they cannot be me. I must be more careful in the future. I cannot make this game too easy for you. Otherwise where would the fun be in it for me? Now, shall we continue to watch this story unfold? Oh and I shall make this kid friendly. In case of foul language I shall use my power to block it from your mind. I will not taint you more than you already are. Now, on to the story!”

“Hey Chris! Hey! Hey! Want to come over to my place? Mom’s making hamburger tonight. She was asking about you the other day too. Wondering why you haven’t come over as often. And my little brother wants to know when you two can play video games again.”

“I’d like that Chel. But I have a few things I need to do first. How about you run on ahead and I will see you in a little bit.”

“What do you got to do huh? You live alone and you aren’t in any clubs. So where are you always heading off to in secret? I know! You’re like some secret agent in disguise aren’t you? Like in those anime. A high school student by day and a crime fighting giant robot pilot by night.”

“Yeah you caught me. I’m a regular superhero. I work for a secret government agency fighting off aliens from outer space in robots as tall as a house. We wipe everyone’s memories after every attack and fill in all the holes we create when the enemy explodes.”

“Sweet! I knew it! Will you take me on a ride in your mech then? Just a quick waltz around the world fighting the bad guys? A little spice to the day?”

“I can do that. And have you home in time for dinner.”

Chel whirled around on one foot laughing gaily. Hopping and skipping around me before wrapping her
arms around my neck from behind and pressing herself against my back. I felt her weight as she let her knees drop a bit and braced myself so she wouldn’t pull me over.

“That’s why I like you Chris. You’re always willing to play along with my wild imagination. You don’t think I’m weird or look sideways at the strange things I say either. You accept me for who I am. I’m glad you are my best friend.”

“Yeah friends forever. Nothing more, nothing less.”

“Exactly!”

She pushed herself away from me and skipped ahead while I fought down the lump in my throat. Friend zoned again. Sometimes her callous words could really hurt. It was like she didn’t remember my confessions at all. Though in truth she probably didn’t. She waved goodbye as she ran off down the street. I simply waved back until she was out of sight. Once I was sure she wouldn’t come running back on some whim I turned and headed for the group of boys that had been following us since the school building. I knew what they were after, a rematch. I had no problems with giving them all a beat down yet again. Ten or ten hundred, I would protect Chel no matter what.

“Oh now this is quite interesting. We have two divergent paths here. One a boy with unrequited love and a self appointed mission, the other a ditzy girl clueless to the world around her. Seemingly unconcerned with the feelings of the one closest to her. So now then, tell me dear viewer, you are god. Or at least you have a portion of my power. Following both of them at the same time is too much for you right now. But you may follow one or the other. So which one do you chose? Which one shall you follow? The boy? Or the girl?”
1.title: A normal day begins...

11.content:
“Hmm interesting, you chose to follow the boy. You already taken a fancy to him? Oh I’m not judging. Far be it from me to judge your tastes. Oh I know, it’s the whole driven hero you like huh? That bad boy behind the smiles. Well it was your choice, lets see what interesting things he might get into.”

“Don’t you guys ever give up? This is what, the fourth time now? Just accept the beatings you already got and back off.”

“We got us a secret weapon this time. My brother’s friend goes to another school and he got the meanest, baddest, strongest guy there for us. With him on our side there aint no way we can lose!”

“Geez. Do you even hear yourself? You sound like a bad TV show. Isn’t it about time you grew up and moved on? We aren’t in middle school anymore you know. Getting someone else to fight your battles for you is like saying I’m going to get my big brother after you. If you want to fight me that’s fine. But do it with your own strength. Otherwise what’s the point?”

“I don’t care who’s strength I use! As long as I get to knock that cocky smirk of your face and ground you into the dust I’ll use any means necessary!”

I let out a sigh as I pulled the fingerless glove out of my pocket and slid my right hand into it. Once that was done I shoved my left hand back into my pocket, hooking the edge with the web between my thumb and index finger.

“All right, bring him out then. Let’s get this over with quickly. I’ve got other places I need to be. It’s been a while since I had hamburger steak and I don’t want to miss it.”

I motioned with my fingers at them after extending my right arm. The leader of this group, Yushihito, grinned and called for someone to come out. A big burly boy who stood at least a head and a half taller then me at around six foot five stepped into the deserted parking lot from the sidewalk. He walked up to me and looked me in the eye, sizing me up and down. I gave him the same once over, assessing his strength and skill like he was assessing mine.

“A runt like you is my opponent?”

“Better than having my head in the clouds and unable to see.”

“You don’t look so tough to me.”

“Perhaps that’s just because you are too weak. You aren’t able to grasp just how strong I am.”

He grunted and pulled back his fist. As he let it fly forward I cocked back my own right hand and let fly to meet him. At the last moment we slowed our punches down and gave a fist pound in greeting.

“Good to see you again Richard.”

“Same to you Chris. Thanks again for that help you gave me last month. You were right, Amy loved it.”

“Told you. Girls dig the romantic stuff. A bit of soft music, a fancy dinner. Just make them feel they are the only one in the world and that day was created just for them and they are like putty. But I only helped you patch things up for her birthday remember. It’s up to you to keep it together.”

“I know. I might be a bit slow but I aint dumb. I learned my lesson. By the way, got an extra pair of tickets to Rising Zombies next Saturday. Want ‘em?”

“You sure?”

“Yeah I was going to take Amy but she has plans with her folks and I was never big into them like she was.”

“Then hell yeah I’ll take ‘em!”

“Cool. See you tomorrow for our study session?”

“Of course. I’ll make sure you ace that make-up test.”

Richard grinned and waved farewell, turning to leave the parking lot. Yushihito put his hand on his arm to stop him. Richard looked at him with a raised eyebrow but the boy was too stupid to back off. That was the problem with these kinds of people. Always feeling they had something to prove. Feeling a need to act bad or cool all the time. To the point that common sense and brains just flew out the window.

“Wait a minute! We paid you! You’re supposed to kick his *** for us!”

“Oh that’s right. You guys did pay me. But he’s cool. I don’t need your money anyway.”

He dug into his pocket and tossed a small wad of bills in the boys direction. Yushihito fumbled it in the air a moment before catching it and looking at Richard in surprise. I began pulling my glove off as I called after his retreating back.

“You still doing that whole payment for a roughing up shtick?”

He didn’t even turn as he answered.

“Of course. It shows me they are serious. If I listened to every butt hurt idiot wanting me to fight their battles I’d never get any sleep. See ya tomorrow.”

I could see Yushihito’s face getting red at being embarrassed in front of his little gang. It was only six boys aside from him so I wasn’t that worried. I thought he would be smart enough to know when to back down. Even a punk like him had to know when to run and fight another day. But his next words showed just how stupid he really was.

“Get them both! No one plays us like that! Make them regret it!”

His gang all picked up baseball bats and lead pipes they had been hiding behind the cars and charged at us. One of them swung at Richard as he was turning around. He caught it in his left hand and gave the boy a mighty right uppercut with his ham sized fist. The punk was knocked senseless as he flew through the air straight towards me. Deftly I stepped to the side and timed my blow, doing a spinning jump kick as he came down. My attack hit him in the small of his back and sent him flying into two more punks that were charging at me. As I landed I knelt down a moment before shoving off while spinning on the heel of my foot. I caught a third punk under the chin with my knee before turning to find my next opponent. Richard had finished off the other two henchmen, leaving only the leader quivering in his boots.

“Well it looks like the score is tied three-three. That one there is the tiebreaker.”

“Rock-paper-scissors for him?”

“Nah. I’ve already slapped him around three times already. You can have him.”

He grinned and cracked his knuckles as I turned and left the parking lot. If I hurried I could stop at the store and grab some cake or something to take over to Chel’s house. I tuned out the screams of pain coming from the lot behind me, whistling a tune I had heard once a long time ago.

The tune caught in my throat as an image of brown eyes flashed through my mind. Eyes that belonged to the singer of that tune. It had been a long time since I had thought about her. I wonder how she was doing now. Did she even still remember me? Did she even remember Chel?

I shook my head and put those kinds of thoughts out of my mind. History had proven it did no good to dwell on such things. It only made me hurt inside for no benefit. I had chosen my path just as she had. Those paths just happened to go separate ways.

After a few more steps the memories faded and I began whistling again. Though not her song this time.
11.title: Follow Chris!

111.content:
The door opened only seconds after I knocked. Mr. Winter greeted me like a long lost son like he always did and ushered me into the house. I grinned at him as I slipped my shoes off and stepped up into the main hall.

“Honey! I’m home!”

Mr. Winter chuckled at my usual exclamation. I was expecting Chel to come out like she normally did and try to glomp me. Then we would banter back and forth a moment or two and we would all move on with the evening.

Bur Chel didn’t appear. That was odd. It had never happened before. Billy did come running down the steps though, launching himself from the last step to squeeze me around the waist.

“Bro!”

I ruffled his hair as he grinned up at me. He was pretty tall at fourteen, though he had yet to go through a growth spurt. His head coming up barely to the middle of my chest. Another set of pounding feet on the stairs a moment later and another boy was standing in front of me.

“Bro, this is Sam, a friend from school. Sam this is Chris. He isn’t really my brother but he’s cool.”

He put his hand next to his mouth and whispered loud enough so everyone could hear.

“He likes my sister. It’s only a matter of time until he becomes my brother for real.”

“I think your sister might have something to say about that squirt.”

“You’ll win her over. And I’ll help. Just tell me what you want me to do.”

I ruffled his hair again as we shared a conspiratorial wink as Mrs. Winter came out of the kitchen wiping her hands. She smiled when she saw me as well, opening her arms and inviting me into a hug which I accepted. Everything else was normal about this visit, so why did I feel so uneasy all of a sudden?

“Chel is finishing up in the kitchen dear. Dinner will be ready in about an hour.”

“Sweet! Then you can help us with our homework right? And then we can play Splat after dinner!”

Billy began tugging on my arm and pulling me upstairs and I let him. I didn’t mind helping with homework but I told him we would have to see about video games afterwards. He didn’t seem to hear me but that wasn’t unusual.

Before I knew it I was in his room sitting on his bed while him and Sam plopped down in chairs at his desk. But instead of starting into the papers in front of him he swung around to face me, pulling his feet up onto the seat as well.

“I heard you confessed to sis and she shot you down.”

“I heard you wanted me to help you with your homework.”

“Pfft. I don’t need no help. This stuff is easy. I just wanted to hear the dirt on your confession.”

“Little busybody aren’t you?”

“Come on tell me please? Maybe give me some tips on what to do? Or not to do?”

“What? Got your eyes on someone?”

“Maybe.”

So I told him how it happened. How I had gone with the standard confession in an empty classroom after school. And her just as quick reply. He asked a few questions and I answered as best I could. From the direction of his questions he did have someone he liked and wanted to ask out. I finally just told him to go for it. There was no “perfect” time and place. If he waited to say anything it would end up being too late.

“Dinner’s ready!”

I glanced at the door in surprise. Had it really been an hour already? I always seemed to lose track of time while I was here. Everyone just made me feel like I belonged when I came over. But I couldn’t forget myself. Couldn’t get too comfortable. I had to keep my distance if I wanted to keep Chel from getting hurt.

Only half my mind was on my surroundings as I followed Billy down the steps and into the dining room. The other half was mulling over the uneasiness that kept growing inside of me. Chel hadn’t even come upstairs to say hi. She might have been busy with dinner but she would have normally found time to see me, if even for a moment. This wasn’t how things were supposed to be. Had something happened between the time I had left her until now? Had I somehow done something to upset her?

“Pass the potatoes please.”

After handing over the bowl I cut another piece of meat off and stuck it in my mouth. Why wouldn’t she look me in the eyes? In fact she seemed to act like I wasn’t even here. This was not how it was supposed to be. I needed to get to the bottom of this. Needed to fix this somehow. But I couldn’t worry anyone else. I could already see them all looking sideways at me because I was so silent. I wasn’t acting normal either.

"This is good Mrs. W. Been a while since I had hamburger steak.”

“Please how many times have I told you to call me mom. I mean you’re practically family anyway.”

“But I’m not family yet so I don’t feel right calling you mom.”

“He’s never going to be family so you should just drop it mom.”

Chel’s reply, while more like her normal retort, lacked the usual vibrancy and cheerfulness she usually had. I dropped the subject and simply finished eating, having a bit of small talk but otherwise keeping quiet. Once dinner was over I helped clear the table before helping Mrs. Winter wash dishes. She shooed me away after only a moment, saying it was her job not mine. That I was a guest. I feigned being hurt by her words but left her to her own devices when she giggled at my theatrics.

Heading upstairs I ran into Chel who looked away as she tried to slip past to go downstairs. I snagged her arm before she could go anywhere and forced her to look at me.

“What’s up with you Chel?”

“Nothing.”

“Don’t give me that line of bull. You’ve been avoiding me since I got here. You were the one who invited me over remember? You haven’t been acting at all like yourself. So spill it. What’s wrong?”

She pulled her arm out of my grasp. “I said nothing was wrong! Just drop it all right?”

When she again tried to slip past me I barred her path with a hand against the wall.

“Not good enough. I’ve known you too long and there is something bugging you. Is it something I said or did? Somebody threaten you? Tell me. I have this uneasy pit in my stomach and I can’t just let this drop.”

“Just leave me alone already!”

“I can’t leave you alone! I’m your friend Chel!”

“But you don’t want to be right! You want to be more and I don’t! Everybody wants us to be more. Always saying we should hook up. Making offhand comments about how you are part of the family! It never stops! That’s the problem! Why don’t you all just drop it! I bet you are still acting like my friend because you think it will help you get in my pants!”

I slapped her across the face before she could go on.

“Stop talking right there. I like you. I won’t deny that. You saying you didn’t want to go out didn’t suddenly change that fact. But I’m happy being your friend if that’s all you want. I’ll get over you eventually and I will find someone else. But that doesn’t change the facts. Whether we date or not you are still my friend.”

She reached up and rubbed her cheek while looking at me in surprise.

“You hit me!”

“And I’ll do it again if you keep talking stupid like that.”

“I bet you don’t even love me anyway.”

It was only a mumble but I heard it as she looked away from me with downcast eyes. I couldn’t hold myself back anymore. My emotions were already high and those words were like a stab through the heart. I grabbed her shoulders suddenly, making her look at me in surprise. Before she could react I planted my lips on hers and pulled her in close. I could feel her rigid body in my arms as I tried to convey my feelings to her in that single kiss. Finally I pulled away and stared into her beautiful eyes.

“That is how much I love you. Even if you forget it I never will.”

She blinked at me a moment before tearing herself out of my embrace and running downstairs. I watched her pass her mom and dad who were looking up at us around the banister with grins on their faces. She ran to the door and slipped on her shoes before racing into the night.

I heard a creaking behind me and turned in time to see Billy and Sam opening the bedroom door wider, their faces still peeking around the frame. When Billy noticed me looking at him he whistled and gave me a thumbs up sign.

“Aren’t you going to chase after her?”

“No. I said my piece. She needs time to be alone and sort it out herself. I don’t want to push her too much.”

“That’s my big brother, the ladies man. I want to be just like you when I grow up.”

“No you don’t. You have no idea how lucky you have it squirt.”

I headed downstairs to slip on my shoes.

“I think it best if I go home now. I doubt she will want to see me when she gets back. Let her know I’m going to drop the matter. I know how she feels about me and I would like to go back to normal tomorrow. I didn’t mean to actually kiss her, but I’m not sorry I did.”

“You don’t see any of us complaining do you? Maybe that will wake her up and she will finally admit she likes you.”

I gave them a final parting wave before heading off down the street towards my house. Things were about to change. I could feel it in my bones.

“Oh yeah, things just got steamy up in here. This Chris is a regular smooth operator. A little rough around the edges but give him a few years and he could have all the women falling for him. I really want to see what happens to him next. But I also want to know what Chel is thinking. Ok, that’s a bit of a lie, I already know what they are both thinking, but you don’t. I can’t give away too much as long as you are around. So I am trying to act more human for you. So you can identify with me more. Is it working? Well what will you choose?”
111.title: Continue to follow Chris

1112.content:
I glanced around the block to make sure no one was following me. This wasn’t the day someone was supposed to break into my house but with the way the rest of the night had gone I wouldn’t take anything for granted. Something wasn’t right here. The normal course of events had been thrown off. This was the fifty or sixtieth time I had seen everything unfold now and not once had it unraveled like this.

I slid my fingers over the top of the door frame until I touched the hidden switch. Only after pushing down on it to disarm the explosives did I open the door. Once safely inside I touched the switch on the inside lintel to rearm them, locking the door for good measure. I kicked my shoes off and dug into my pockets, laying their contents down on the stand next to the door.

Always second guess and never assume. That is the one unbroken rule to staying alive. I can’t stop you from making this choice. I hold no grudge against you so I will give you this advice to do with what you will. If you truly wish to protect her then do it with all your might. Do not feel anything you do is too low to stoop. Become a monster that all other monsters fear to cross. That is how you survive and that is how you will ultimately be able to protect her. If you balk or think something is distasteful to do, that is when you are sunk. That will be the undoing and will end up hurting or even killing her.

His words echoed in my mind as powerful as the day he said them to me. I thought of him as a second father. Even though I had not seen him in such a long time I still respected him. I had imagined growing up to be just like him. In all honesty if it hadn’t been for the skills he had drilled into me I would have probably been killed many times over by now. Hand to hand, strategy, knives, guns, speed, strength. He had taught all of that and more to me. And now I could use it to protect Chel.

As I sat on the couch and flicked on the TV I pulled up my left pant leg pulling out the gun holstered there. Double checking to make sure the safety was still on. Once I was sure it wouldn’t fire on accident and it still had a full clip, I sat it on the coffee table in front of me. I stomped the floor with my boot and the knife flicked out of the tip. I hit the heel again to retract the blade. I had just oiled the mechanism yesterday but you could never bee too sure. Once that was taken care of I slipped the knife out from under my right pant leg and began sharpening it on the whetstone I had left on the table this morning.

Tomorrow was the turning point. The time when things would start going to hell in a hand basket. When the alliances would start to form and this city would become a war zone. I would protect Chel just like I always did. I would make sure she didn’t die. And I would become a monster that all other monsters fear to cross in order to do so. Even if that meant I had to disappear from her life. That our carefree days together were coming to a close. I had been down this road before. Seen the outcome a dozen times.

From day one I had known what her answer would be. I had asked a dozen different ways in a dozen different places and always it was the same. It never changed what was going to happen. But still I couldn’t help but try. Still I couldn’t help but cherish the moments we had together. Cherish the moments she would remember me. I was part and yet apart from the flow of time here. The course of events that would transpire. In the end I would start over and we would meet for the first time again, we would be happy and carefree, and then the war would again break out.

We were trapped, her and I. Living our own lives, our own lies. Never moving forward past the last day of school. Doomed to repeat the same days over and over. Repeat the same mistakes, the same words with only little variation. In those times when I was a part of her life we would always be nothing but friends. In the ones where I only followed her from the shadows I wasn’t even a memory.

It had been so hard seeing her live over and over. Loving her so much but not having her remember me. Not having her remember the passion we had shared. To see her stare at me blankly as we passed each other on the street. I had been told to let her go. Told to move on. But I couldn’t. I was a fool in love. It had been so long since I had kissed her like that. Since I held her in my arms as she molder herself to my body. I could still taste her lips on mine. That taste igniting distant memories. I hadn’t meant to kiss her, but I was glad I had. It reminded me of what I was fighting for.

I finished sharpening the knife, testing it on a scrap of paper and nodded to myself when it cut it like soft butter. It would cut human flesh just as easily. Slamming it back home in its sheath I got up, heading to the locked room in the back. My fingers slipped behind the nearby painting to pull out the key. A quick turn and I was inside. As I flicked on the light I looked at the photo on the desk next to me.

“Evening mom, evening dad. Uncle Chris. You all probably think I’m stupid don’t you? You’d probably laugh to see me now. Well maybe you wouldn’t. You all went through some amazing adventures together and overcame worse trials then this. You understand these feelings don’t you? Probably better then I understand them myself. Will you give me strength just one more time? Help me bear it once again?”

There was no answer of course. There never was. But their grins said it all. Their static smiles gave me confidence. I nodded my head to them before turning to the room at large. I ignored the far wall that I had covered with a list of all the events that had and would take place. All the pins and strings of interconnected happenings of cause and effect that made up this world up until school ended. The pitfalls, the ambushes, the hotspots that could put Chel in danger. All there for me to keep her from dying. To put an end to trouble before she walked into it.

Instead I focused on the other three walls filled with every and any weapon someone could imagine and some that only existed because I wanted them to. I had to be prepared for tomorrow. And for the day after. And the day after that. I already knew who the big bad was. The great evil I would end up fighting. But simply walking up and killing him would do no good. I had already tried that tactic three times. This world had ways to fix such glitches. Another big bad would pop up and things would continue on like always. So I would play my part and say my lines. Forever and ever. No matter how much I changed the story, it never moved on past that last day..

I slipped a giant sword off the wall and swung it around a few times before hitting the switch under the hilt. The blade broke up and folded in on itself until all I held was a small dagger. Another flick of the button restored it to its regular size. I laid it to the side as I reached for a sawed off shotgun. Hefting it in my hand a moment I finally discarded it as too bulky. Maybe save it for next week when the puppet master showed up. Though I could use the spring loaded knife launcher. Many people were going to die tomorrow, but Chel wouldn’t be one of them.

“Oh interesting. By the sounds of it, it seems like he is a descendant of Conolaunis. Of course you would know him better as Chrono, the god of time. He got my power to travel back and forth through time as he wished. Giving him an ability akin to prophecy. It seems he is quite smitten with this girl, to repeat this time over and over. But even he cannot easily cheat death. Surely he must have tried already and found just how hard it is. If a person is fated to die then they have no choice but to die at their appointed time. Replaying the timeline can’t change that so easily. The only one of my children with that power aside from me is the one you call the grim reaper.”

“Why don’t I save this girl from dying if I have such power you ask? Well why should I? What is the life of a mere mortal to me? Everything has its time and place. She is fated to die. In a sense she has already died. Messing with the balance of things isn’t an easy matter, even for a god. That is why it is simply easier for me to observe and not get involved. Well, not get involved until I am bored anyway.”
1112.title: I can't leave Chris alone

11121.content:
“Sorry dear, Chelsea isn’t feeling all that well. It seems she came down with a slight cold last night. So she won’t be going to school today.”

“I understand Mrs. W. Make sure to let her know that I hope she gets better soon. Also to stay away from the church over on Peach for a few days. I heard they have a bit of an asbestos problem and are cleaning it up. I don’t want her breathing any of it in by accident.”

“I’ll make sure to let her know. Have a good day at school.”

Turning from the front door I headed off down the street with Billy next to me. He started talking about a video game and I tuned him out with half my mind. Putting that part to work on what I had to do today. In all honesty her not going to school actually worked in my favor. Even though this was not the way things were supposed to go it was just a minor glitch. It wouldn’t affect the course of events that much. But now that she had decided to play hooky from school I didn’t have to start an argument with the class president as an excuse to ditch.

“That was a pretty bold move last night.”

“Hmm? Oh yeah it was. I didn’t really plan on doing it. It sort of… just happened.”

“Hey bro. Do… do you think…”

“No.”

“No? What do you mean?”

“You were just going to ask if I could teach you how to kiss like that or something along those lines.”

“I… I was not!”

“Oh? My mistake then. What were you going to say?”

“I…I was going to say do you think my sister will want to go out with you now?”

“Sure that was what you were going to ask. I total believe you. Good recovery though. So I’ll give you an A. But it is a good question. Honestly it could go either way. She could either want to go out or never want to see me again. Besides kissing isn’t something you can really be taught, you just got to learn it on your own.”

We walked on in silence for a bit until we came to the bridge a few blocks from Peach street. Even during the normal course of events Chel would be in school when things went down there. Still I had to warn her away because you could never be too careful. A quick glance at my watch told me I had about half an hour before I needed to be at the church, plenty of time. As Billy turned onto the bridge I noticed a girl waiting there. To most it would look like she had seemingly stopped to look down into the river, but I knew. Even if I hadn’t seen this scene multiple times. She was waiting for Billy.

I glanced over at the boy and saw the bit of star struck wonder in his eyes. The whole look of being
around someone you have a crush on. I could see the girl glancing sideways at him as well, the same bit of infatuation glimmering behind her locks of hair. I pulled the boy to the side and knelt in front of him, whispering so only he could hear me.

“Why don’t you ask her to walk home with you today? I’ll be a bit late so I won’t be able to meet up with you like I normally do.”

“W-what are you talking about!”

“Oh don’t play dumb. You like her and I bet she likes you too. Perhaps she will let you practice kissing with her eh? But you got to start somewhere. Walking her home will get you a lot of points with her.”

“But I can’t do that! I get tongue tied when I am around her!”

“I see.”

I stood up and let him go. As he caught up to her on the bridge and the two of them turned to walk to school I called after them.

“Hey Billy! Aren’t you going to introduce me to your girlfriend?”

“She’s not my girlfriend!”

He was turning beet red as he spun around to face me, his shoulders hunched a bit. I simply grinned at him as the girl also turned around blushing and looking away. Finally he held out his hand as if showcasing her off.

“This is Rachael. She’s just a friend from school. Rachael this is Chris. He’s sort of like my big brother.”

She gave me a smile and a polite bow, a favor which I returned.

“May I ask where you live?”

“Over by the high school.”

“Perfect! I need to stay a bit late there today and I usually go home with Billy. His mom doesn’t like him walking home alone you see. So would it be ok if he walks you home today? Then it will be a hop skip and a jump to my school where he can wait for me.”

I could see Billy miming frantically behind her and I had a hard time keeping my face straight so as not to give him away. The girl blushed a bit before nodding her head.

“I don’t mind. My mom would feel better that I was walking home with someone too. She doesn’t like that I walk to school alone.”

“Great! It’s settled. I’ll treat you both to some ice cream someday for doing me this favor. It was a pleasure to meet you Rachael.”

I turned and jogged off, letting the two of them go on their way, grinning like a fool. Even after all this time I still had the capacity to do things like this instead of simply observing. That was a good thing. It meant I wasn’t too jaded. As I passed the church I scoped out the area, doubling back after a block to sneak up on it from behind. I knew from previous times the front was guarded but the back had almost no one. I knew I probably shouldn’t get involved in all of this. But I was tired of simply watching it all happen. Besides this was one of the key points. If I neutralize this group now, Chel wouldn’t be in danger later.

I was about to break from cover and make a dash to the back door when two men in ski masks came out. This had never happened before. This was more then just a small glitch in the system. This was altering the timeline completely. First yesterday and now this, just what was going on?

The two of them were talking to each other in undertones. As they drew closer to the bushes I was hiding in, one of them turned to the other to laugh. Using this opportunity I sprang out of hiding,clamping a hand on each of their throats, triggering the quick release blades against my wrists to snap open. I dragged them both into the darkness of the bushes as they gave their last gurgling attempts at sound. Retracting the blades just as quickly as I had inserted them.

I couldn’t completely trust in what I knew now. Someone or something was manipulating the timelines and throwing them off. I had to be extra careful. For all I knew this church would go up in flames any second now and not in another forty minutes. I made sure my gun’s safety was off before silently opening the back door and slipping inside.

Empty. Just like it should be. This was the basement of the church. A big empty room with a small kitchen area. A stage to the left where they had probably held Christmas shows or something and three steps in front of me and to the right leading up to a small walled off second floor. Then two sets of stairs, one right next to me and one on the raised floor leading up to the main part of the church. It all looked normal.

To anyone who didn’t know any better. This church had once been part of an underground network that housed refugees and slaves. There were catacombs peppering the foundation of the building that had been long forgotten about. I made my way up to the raised floor and over to a janitors closet. Ignoring the strong stench of cleaning solution that assaulted my nostrils, I headed straight for the back wall where I turned the emergency water cut off switch. After that I popped the cold water knob off and shoved in on the exposed metal pin.

The entire wall behind the tub inset into the floor swung silently away from me. Allowing me to proceed down the now revealed stairs. When I got to the bottom I palmed my .45, double checking to make sure the silencer was securely fastened. There would be two guards. One to the left and one to the right of the door. Ten seconds was all I needed. Turn, aim, shoot. Just like the last four times I had done this. I took a deep breath and swung around the wall with my weapon raised.

Only to find the two guards unconscious on the floor already. I lowered my weapon only slightly. This was new. This had never happened before. I quickly moved up on them in a crouch, feeling their necks and finding a pulse. Not dead. Whoever had done this must not have had the stomach to finish the job. I put the gun to the first guys head and fired before moving to the second guard and doing the same thing. They were dead now. No chance of them waking up and screwing me over.

I pushed open the door with the barrel of my gun, ready to shoot at a moments notice. I spied someone standing about five foot tall with black hair in front of the woman I had come to rescue. I aimed my weapon at the back of his head. Friend or foe, I couldn’t take the chance. I had never seen him before and he had never been in this room any other time I had done this. His back went rigid for a moment and I saw his shoulders tense. He grabbed Robin and threw himself to the floor just as I fired. As I swung my weapon down on him he raised his hands in surrender.

“Don’t shoot! I’m one of the good guys! I’m here to rescue the girl. I assume that’s what you are here for as well? Your names Chris right? He said you might come. I’m Yuki Kamishiro. But we can save the explanations for later. Right now we need to get out of here.
11121.title: What's Chris up to?

111211.content: Are you daft? Did you forget already? I only gave you the power to watch and know what the players are thinking! I never gave you any power to control their actions! So whether he shoots or not is up to him. But your decision at least tells me the kind of person you are. Remind me never to put my life in your hands. Lets keep watching and see what goes down.
111211.title: Shoot

1112111.content:
Swinging my weapon away from him I grunted my assent. Peeking around the door frame and covering him while he cut Robin’s ropes. No one was supposed to show up for another five minutes, but with the way things were going I wouldn’t be surprised if someone jumped out of the ground in front of me yelling happy birthday. Who was this guy anyway? He was no part of this timeline. No part of any timeline that I had lived through anyway. But I could afford to make a temporary alliance with him. I knew I could kill him later if he betrayed me.

“Hey. Yuki right? How’d you take out the guards anyway?”

“I just slipped up behind them and hit them on the back of the neck.”

“So you know martial arts huh?”

“No. I’m not much of a fighter at all. I just… know how to effectively defend myself.”

“Why didn’t you kill them?”

“No need. Incapacitating them was all that was needed. Besides, I don’t like to kill.”

“You ever kill anyone before?”

“… No.”

“Well I took care of them for you.”

“You mean you killed them?”

“Yes. I’ve learned not to leave potential threats alive.”

“Oh.”

I glanced back to see him looking at the floor a moment as he swallowed. I noticed the hand gripping the knife was ghost white from the pressure he was exerting. He hesitated only a moment before cutting the last of Robin’s bonds. She lost no time in pulling the gag out of her mouth and looking at me a bit wildly.

“Chris! Just what the hell is going on here? I suddenly get kidnapped, blindfolded and brought to this dingy underground room. Where are we and just who are you to talk about killing people so easily?”

“No time for explanations. Leave it at they want your brother’s power and they kidnapped you to get it. But this place is dangerous. The people who took you are in a war with another group who will send this place up in flames shortly. We need to get out now. So just keep quiet and follow me.”

She started to say something else and the Kamishiro fellow silenced her.

“He’s right. There’s more to the story obviously but he covered it in a nutshell. This place is going to explode in about ten minutes.”
Ten? It wasn’t supposed to explode for another thirty. Did he know something I didn’t? I had no time to think of that now. We just had to get moving. I led the two of them out into the hall. Yuki turned slightly green at seeing the dead bodies and so did Robin. I ignored them both, expecting them to stick close, something they had no problem doing.

“You got a weapon aside from that knife?”

“No. I don’t need any.”

“That won’t fly with me. I’d feel safer if you had something to defend yourself with at range. Not all enemies will let you get close enough for a karate chop to the neck.”

I grabbed the barrel with my hand and held out the butt of the pistol for him to grab. He put his hands up in the air and shook his head quickly. With a sigh I grabbed his right hand and shoved the weapon into it.

“Really easy. Just point in the general direction and pull the trigger. It doesn’t matter right now if you hit anything or not. They will take cover as long as it is pointing in their general direction.”

For a moment he seemed more afraid of my contact than the gun itself. He slowly blinked and looked down at his hand in surprise and back at me, his mouth opening and closing but no sound coming out.

“You’re just like him! I can’t see you! You exist but at the same time you don’t! You’re outside the flow of time!””

My insides went cold at his words. How did he know that? And who was this other person I was like? No time for that now. Concentrate on escaping you idiot. Peeking around the corner I saw two men coming down the stairs. This much at least was still the same. I motioned with my hands for them to stay here and they nodded their heads that they understood. Slipping my fingers up under my shirt I pulled out two throwing knives that were laying against my sides. Flipping them and holding the tips gently. I silently counted out the seconds. At ten I sprinted around the corner.

Both of them had their backs to me, pointing off down into the darkness of another tunnel. I let fly with both blades, the first one embedding into the back of the one on the lefts neck. But the second one missed as the other guy suddenly moved. Couldn’t anything go exactly as it was supposed to today? As the first body dropped and the guy who had gotten lucky began to turn I stomped on the heel of my right foot seconds before bringing it up and around to crash into the side of his head. He stared at me in surprise before the life drained out of him. With a slightly wet sucking sound I pulled the blade out of his ear and retracted it back into my boot.

Quickly I retrieved my dagger from the first mans neck, wiping it off on his shirt before gathering the other two. They took one look at the bodies on the floor and then looked away, trying to not see them through force of will. Leading them upstairs I peeked through the eyehole to make sure no one would see us exiting. When I was sure it was clear we entered the janitors closet. I could hear sounds of fighting coming from upstairs. The clash of steel on steel and the sounds of gunfire. Thirty seconds. We needed to wait thirty seconds. Slipping my hand up my pant leg I pulled out another gun. This one had no silencer so I needed to be careful.

At exactly thirty seconds the knob on the door began to turn. I shoved on it hard, smacking the woman opening it in the face. As she reeled back I dashed out of the closet and stuck the weapon under her chin, pulling the trigger. Luckily my gunshot was covered by the sound of what sounded like a sub machine gun going off upstairs.

“Can you see the future too?”

“You could say that I guess. Though this is a future I have never seen. Now enough chatter. We aren’t out of here yet. Now we run.”

The three of us ran for all we were worth to the door. I easily outpaced them, yanking the door open just as they got there. Yuki suddenly turned around and fired his weapon, clipping the man who was just coming down the far stairs in the leg. He gave a short cry of pain as he fell. As he was getting back up I put a bullet between his eyes. He wasn’t supposed to be there either. Ushering them out the back door I slammed it shut behind me. It only took a few moments after that to get a few blocks away.

“Thought you said you had never shot a gun before.”

“I haven’t.”

“Well that was a pretty accurate shot.”

“I knew he was going to be there, I saw where I had to aim. It was nothing special.”

“Next time aim for the heart, head, or throat. Shoot to kill.”

“I don’t want there to be a next time.”

“Suit yourself. But that kind of thinking will get you killed one of these days. But now that we are out of the woods for the moment, how bout you tell me just what the hell is going on. Why were you there? Who am I just like? Why is the timelines so screwed up?”

My phone began to buzz in my pocket and I let out a sigh of displeasure as I pulled it out. I had to do a double take as it showed the tracer I had planted in Chel’s cell phone running straight for the church.

“God **** stupid woman! Can’t she follow just a simple request? Why now of all times!”

I looked at Yuki and then at Robin.

“Get out of here. I’ll find you later. And when I do I want answers.”

When Yuki went to hand me the gun back I shook my head.

“Keep it. You might need it later.”

With that I headed off back to the church, making a beeline for the tracer position. When I rounded the corner I saw a woman let go of Chel and begin running off down the street.

“Who was that?”

“I don’t know. She said she was my mother.”

I looked again at the now empty street, narrowing my eyes in speculation. No it couldn’t be. It wasn’t possible.

“Do you know her?”

“No… She just reminded me of someone I once knew. Anyways what are you doing here? I thought I told you not to come around the church for a bit.”

“I could ask you the same thing. What are you doing here? Shouldn’t you be in school?”

I shrugged. “I ditched. Just like you did. But that still doesn’t answer my question, why are you here?”

She opened her mouth to answer when the street was rocked by a giant explosion. I braced my feet as Chel lost hers. I looked back quickly to see the church had indeed gone up in flames earlier then it was supposed to. I felt the adrenaline rushing through me. The thrill of battle underway. Perhaps I was a bit mad. Had a bit of what they called battle crazies. But I was ready for this war. This was my element. Where I felt most at home sometimes. But it was also the start of the end. Soon I would disappear from Chel’s life yet again. Then it would start all over.

“Our friend Chris here is a bit of a killer isn’t he? Puts a bit of a new twist on the phrase: a love to die for, don’t you think? Or perhaps he has some… killer kisses? I wonder if perhaps he might have… jumped the gun?”

“Ok, ok. I’m done. Didn’t think those were funny? Come on work with me here! I’m trying to connect with you, a bit of god to mortal bonding. Make you feel at ease! I heard you mortals say laughter is the best medicine. I’m just trying to understand you! Ah well maybe next time then eh? So what are you going to do now? Follow the bewildered beauty laying on the ground at your feet? Or continue to follow this enigmatic boy wonder?”
1112111.title: Retreat

choices: Is he really dead? I'm not so sure...
Well lets see Chelsea I guess...
11121112.content:
With a shake of my head I returned to the task at hand. Chelsea was starting to get to her feet when the sound of running footsteps made me turn around. Richard came upon us at a jog. What was he doing here? Just what was going on? Everything was following the timeline like it was supposed to, just faster then it was supposed to. The church wasn’t supposed to explode for another twenty minutes, Richard wasn’t supposed to come around here until then either.

Chel saw Richard and pointed at him in surprise.

“You! You’re the guy from last night! Richard Noel right?”

“Aye. And you’re Chelsea Winters.”

“Wait, you two know each other?”

“Yeah he walked me home last night after… after dinner.”

“I didn’t know that trouble you were telling me about was Chris! If I had I would have given you better advice.”

“Like what you oversized muscle factory?”

“Like she should stay as far away from you as possible. That you are nothing but trouble.”

I shook his hand with a smile on my face but inwardly I was grinding my teeth in confusion. Richard and Chel weren’t supposed to meet for another three days. Once everything went to pot and I faked my own death. Then Richard was supposed to meet her for the first time and take care of her. Things were happening too fast and out of order. Just who was messing with the timeline? It was too much to just be coincidence or a few small glitches.

“So what brings you out this way you big idiot?”

He pulled me off to the side and lowered his voice before telling me everything I already knew. About the Inquisition and them trying to use him to destroy half the town by kidnapping his sister. He didn’t know he was being used to destroy half the town of course, but I did. That was the way this story was supposed to go. Before I altered it the first time and every time after that. I reassured him that his sister was safe , quickly telling him where she had been held prisoner before telling him to head over to First and Peach where I had last seen Robin heading.

“Thanks mate. I owe you big time for this. I don’t know how you knew what was going down or how you pulled it off and I don’t want to know. But you saved my sister so that makes anything you did A-Ok in my book.”

“No worries. And if I don’t see you again soon, keep safe and don’t die.”

“Back at you bro.”

I watched him run off, figuring this would be the last time I saw him. If things kept moving this quickly I would have to disappear today instead of a few days from now. Finally I turned to look at Chell who was staring up at the fire still going strong while the sounds of fire trucks kept getting closer. Grabbing her by the shoulders I forced her to look at me.

“Chel. I want you to go home. Run as fast as you can and don’t go outside for anything. For nothing you hear me! I don’t care if someone will grant your every wish if you just step outside. Don’t leave the house.”

“What about you?”

“Don’t worry about me. I’ll be fine. I’ll go get Billy out of school and send him home too. Something big is going down. I don’t know what but it is dangerous. I don’t want you getting hurt.”

“O-Ok. You’ll come home with Billy then right?”

“Of course. I’d hate to die and make you cry.”

She nodded her head and turned to go. I couldn’t help holding onto her arm, refusing to let her go for just a moment longer. She turned to look at me questioningly.

“Chel. Always remember that I love you. For now and forever. No matter what happens.”

I let her go then, turning and running off back towards the flames. If everything was going to happen like it was meant to then the middle school building would be the next to go. In the original timeline before I changed it all up, only a handful of kids would survive and Billy would not be one of them. His body would never be found, consumed in the explosion like so many others. But after seeing the way Chel had broken down that first time I couldn’t bear to see it again. So I had saved him over and over.

As I passed the church a few stragglers laid around on the ground, having made it out of the actual blast but getting thrown by the force afterwards. I left them be. I wasn’t interested in these throwaways that would be caught by the police or killed by someone else within the next ten minutes anyway. When one of them reached up and grabbed my ankle I reached behind my back, grabbing the handle of the knife there and hitting the switch under the hilt. As I swung it around the sword expanded out, slicing the mans arm off while making sparks on the sidewalk. I hit the trigger again, returning it to looking like a dagger on the upwards swing. A deft twirl and I shoved it back into its sheath without losing too much time.

Though why hadn’t the police station blown up yet? Or the jailhouse? In fact why wasn’t half the town in flames already? The church going up should have sparked a chain reaction, the Inquisition people had planted C-4 all over town spreading out from the church after all. This was like a completely new story. I didn’t know what was going on anymore. All I could do was follow what I knew and adapt as I went.

The middle school came into view before I knew it. The generic white washed fence surrounding the building and the closed and locked gate making it seem more like a prison then a place of learning. Especially with a guard inside the booth next tot the gate. I swerved right, heading for a tree planted near enough to the wall to be of use. As I ran I slid my belt buckle off. Pulling out a length of steel cable along with it. A quick swing of the arm and it looped around the branch. I hit the retract button as I ran up the trunk, jiggling the line loose at the last second to let the buckle snap back into place. Running along the branch I jumped just as it started to bow, landing safely on the flat wall top. From there it was a short hop to the ground.

In the normal timeline he would be in history class. But this wasn’t the normal timeline. The church went up twenty minutes early, so I would assume the school would too. What class did he have before history? I didn’t know. Wait! I did know! He had told me once, ten or twelve repeats ago. Gym! Outside sports.

I made a mad dash around the side of the building, skidding to a halt as the track and field area came into view. Looking around madly I finally found him, running around the track.

Ignoring the shouts from teachers saying I wasn’t supposed to be here and the guard that began chasing me with a nightstick in his hand I ran onto the field and caught up to Billy. As I passed him I snatched him up under my arm, ignoring his surprise and heading back to the wall out front. I could go for the walls in the back but most of the explosion would fly that way.

“W-What? Bro! What are you doing? Let me go.”

“Quiet. I’m saving your life. You aren’t safe here.”

“What are you talking about!”

“Do you trust me?”

“Yeah.”

“Then don’t ask questions.”

I was panting a bit by the time we got to the wall. With a quick shove I boosted him to the top.

“What about the others?”

“I can’t save them.”

The guard came up on me then as I told Billy to drop down and wait for me. He dropped to the other side as I turned to face my opponent. The nightstick swung at my head so I ducked under it. Kicking him in the back of the knee and shoving his head towards the ground. He instinctively held his hands out so he wouldn’t smash his face into the dirt. I took advantage of that split second to use his back as a stepping stone, grabbing onto the top of the eight foot tall wall.

Once safely perched on the top with the guard waving his stick uselessly at me, I took one last look at the school. Knowing almost two hundred people would die in this explosion alone. I saw a figure in a third story window looking out at me. Slightly graying hair, an eye patch over one eye and a muscular build. He had a commanding presence even at this distance.

It couldn’t be him. It was impossible. Was he the mastermind behind all of this? First someone claiming to be Chel’s mother and now him? Was that why everything was breaking down from what I knew? I had to find out. I had to be sure.

“Billy. Go home without me. Stay inside all day no matter what. No matter what you see or hear just run straight home.”

“But…!”

“Trust me. Now go.”

He ran. With only one last look he ran away. I watched him go for just a second before jumping off the wall onto the guards head, crushing his skull under my foot before running into the school building. I made it to the first stairwell and had my foot on the first step when the first bomb exploded. I heard them going off in order as those who had time to scream did so before being blown to bits. I saw the far classroom door shoot outwards as the flames bubbled out. A second later the next classroom did the same.

I didn’t have any time left. With a growl of frustration I threw myself over the railing and down the flight into the basement, smashing my hand down on the armlet hidden under my shirt up by my right shoulder. All I could do now was ride it out.

“OH MY… ME! He’s dead! I can’t believe he is dead! Well shows over, lets go check up on someone else shall we? I’m sure Chelsea is still alive and kicking.”
11121112.title: enigmatic boy

111211121.content:
"I'm shocked you don't believe me! Flabbergasted! Indignant even!"

......

"But you are right. Boy wonder isn't dead."

With a groan I shoved a bit of rubble off of me. The fire suit had protected me from the heat of the explosion and the magnetic repulsion shield had stopped the brunt of the building from crushing me. If I had been more prepared for this I could have hunkered down to wait out the destruction better.

Climbing the demolished steps I shoved a bit of broken building out of the way, pulling myself out of my tomb. I was about to head towards the gate when I saw Chel standing there screaming her head off calling my name. What was she doing here? Why hadn’t she gone home?

Wait. This was good. I could vanish from her life now. It would make getting around easier. I wouldn’t have to hide who I really was from her anymore. Wouldn’t have to pretend to be just an ordinary high school student. So instead of coming out into the open, I kept hidden until she eventually left. Once she was gone I headed for the back wall, leaving the ruins of the school behind me.

“I’m sorry Chel. It’s better this way. I’ll see you again in a few weeks when we start things from scratch.”

She couldn’t hear my whispered words of farewell of course, but I imagined they still reached her. A police officer stopped me as I was walking away from the wreckage but I really didn’t have time to deal with him. The time for playing the role of a high school student was over. This was now war. So I brushed his hand off my shoulder and kept walking.

He reached out and grabbed my arm, starting to twist it behind my back saying I was coming with him. With a deft spin I reversed the hold, cranking his arm behind his back seconds before grabbing his neck and snapping it.

“Halt!”

I looked back to see another officer pointing a gun at me and sighed. I really didn’t need this. I put my hands up in surrender as he came towards me. The moment he took his eyes off me to talk into his radio I pulled my own pistol from behind my back and shot him in the head. In all the confusion one or two more dead bodies wouldn’t be noted. That is if this world even cared about throw away characters like this. I’d be surprised if they even had a name.

I needed to get to City hall. That was the next major key point in this series of events. Everything was happening faster than it was meant to. The church, the school, probably even the police station bombing. Other things were happening out of sequence, such as my faked death, Chel meeting Richard, the escalation of this war. Still, what had to happen had still happened even if the order was messed up. That meant City hall was the next target. I had to make sure everyone in the building was caught in the explosion. Or at least I had to make sure the government officials were killed.

It took longer then I thought it would, the streets were already awash with mobs of panicked citizens. The military was already trying to restore order but to no avail. Of course they wouldn’t be effective, they hadn’t been given orders to open fire with live rounds yet. The best they could do was shoot beanbags and tear gas. That would only give them breathing room though, a cleared space only as big as the perimeter they could hold. If they started breaking off and venturing out into the streets alone or in packs of two’s and three’s they would be overrun by the mob.

I skirted their perimeter around the building, glancing up at the fourth story window of the Beechton hotel, seeing the glint of reflection off a sniper scope. Good, that much was still the same. I would just sit in the shadows and take out anyone he missed. He normally didn’t miss anyone but every so often that variation did happen in the timelines. With the way things were going I wouldn’t be surprised if he missed every single one of them.

Another glint from the fourth floor of the Hilington hotel made me pull out my retractable spyglass to check it out. There was someone up there with a sniper rifle as well. There was only supposed to be one shooter, not two. I couldn’t make out his looks clearly because of the reflections in the window but I just knew he wasn’t here to assassinate anyone. This was another glitch to the order of things. I had to put an end to this now.

I slipped into the ally between the Beechton and an Italian restaurant, pulling bags off the pile of garbage in the dumpster there. It took only a moment to uncover the sniper rifle I had planted earlier this morning. Another moment more to grab the clip from where I had taped it under the giant blue dumpster. Securing the silencer onto the tip I flipped the cap off the scope, hefting it to my shoulder before leveling it at the fourth floor window of the Hilington.

Shoot to kill. Guns are weapons, not toys. Pull a gun with the intention of firing it. Brother, sister, mother, friend. These words don’t matter when you point a gun at them. Who might mourn their passing, who might come get revenge, these too do not matter. What matters is your commitment. That is why you must think of all of this before you pull out your weapon. Once it is drawn and pointed, that is your commitment. Your intent to fire and to kill no matter who it is pointed at. Uncle Chris’ words reverberated in my head as I let out my breath slowly and pulled the trigger.

I didn’t have time to confirm the kill though as the side door of the restaurant began to open. Quickly I hopped into the open dumpster and covered myself with the black bags full of garbage, shoving the rifle down along the inside of the metal tub. Yet another glitch that wasn’t supposed to happen. A rain of half eaten food, old sauce and much more dripped down on my head, the bulk of it being stopped by the trash bags. I resisted the urge to gag at the smell as I waited for the sound of the door opening and closing again.

Climbing back out I cleaned myself off as best I could before making sure the rifle still worked. Once I was assured it was fine I waited. I didn’t have to wait long before the City hall building went up like a firecracker. A few bodies flew through the air, flailing their arms wildly before connecting with the ground or denting in a car roof. Hefting it back to my shoulder I used the scope on my weapon to get a better view.

The first congressman came out the door. I waited a moment for the sniper in the hotel next to me to do his job. But nothing happened. With a sigh I took the shot. Instead of going through his head like it should have something hit my bullet in mid air, making a small spark.

What the hell was that? I shot another bullet, and again I failed to kill my target. I picked another one of the officials running out of the building and fired. It flew right in front of his face because he had suddenly stopped. The reason for his sudden halt was because someone had shot the ground right in front of him. I glanced up to the Hilington hotel quickly through my scope. There in the corner room was the glint of a scope. The angle was bad so I couldn’t get a clear shot at him but I knew he was the cause of this. I fired a round in his direction, hoping to cut him up by breaking the window. But he jerked away before it even broke.

My interference did allow the sniper in the hotel next to me to take out one of the officials. Well it was no big deal, even if they made it to their cars, the bombs I had planted early this morning would take them out as soon as they fired up the engine.

Even though I continued to lay down covering fire, the sniper in the other hotel still managed to stop almost all the shots. To make matters worse, instead of getting into their own vehicles, a group of black armored sedans came barreling out of nowhere for the officials to be ushered into. Soon enough all six vehicles were out of sight and only five congressmen and senators had been successfully killed. All in all a total failure.

With a disgusted sigh I broke down the weapon, throwing the parts into the dumpster and covering it over with garbage. It was untraceable and I could always get another easily. The only thing I could do now was go home and get cleaned up. With a little food in me and some clean clothes I could figure out my next step. Figure out how to salvage this mess and correct the course of time. Because at this rate Chel would end up dead tomorrow.

The trek back to the house went by in a daze. A few people took one look at me and gave me a wide berth. I didn’t mind. As long as they didn’t try to stop me. The farther I got from the center of things the less it seemed people knew what was going on or that anything was going on. Soon enough they would though and nowhere in this town would be safe or free of panic.

Reaching up above the door frame to hit the button my fingers froze. It was already depressed. The trap was deactivated. Somebody who knew about the trap had been in my house. They might even still be in there. As silently as I could I opened the door, slipping my glok out of its holster as I did so. The house was quiet and dark just as I had left it, but this was just the entranceway. I couldn’t call it safe from just this.

No. Not completely quiet. I could hear the faint sounds of the TV in the living room. Step by careful step I slid across the floor, cocking back the hammer before twisting around the frame ready to fire at the first thing that moved. Sitting in the chair with his legs crossed and his fingers steepled in front of him was the person I had never thought I would see again. I blinked my eyes rapidly but the vision didn’t change at all. Slowly I lowered my weapon as I felt tears starting to trickle down my face.

He stood with a smile and opened his arms and I ran into them without a second thought, wrapping my arms around his waist as I buried my head in his chest.

“I’ve missed you uncle Chris!”
111211121.title: Is he really dead? I'm not so sure...

1112111211.content:
“I’ve missed you too Cri‘sa.”

“I tried to be strong. But it was so hard. I almost gave up at least a dozen times.”

“But you didn’t. That’s the important thing. Even though no one would have faulted you for letting go, you didn’t. You stayed true to yourself.”

“Why are you here?”

“To correct a mistake I made.”

“You mean…!”

“Yes. I’m going to give her back her memories.”

I suddenly felt lighter then I ever had before. The end was in sight. I hadn’t been strong enough to break her out of the loop. But I knew uncle Chris could. He was the one who had placed her in it after all.

I let go of him and took a step back, wiping my eyes quickly. I was a Jarlepian. I wasn’t supposed to be crying like a normal human over every little thing. He grabbed a cane I now noticed was leaning against the chair and headed off towards the kitchen. Try as I might, my third eye showed that he wasn’t using any kind of disguise technology. His blue eye was probably a colored contact. Other than that it didn’t look like he had altered his appearance at all. I followed him, still in a bit of a stupor.

“So then does that mean aunt Lexi really is here?”

“Aye, how did you know?”

“Chel, I mean Anna said a woman calling herself her mother had stopped her.”

“Ah, that. I already berated her for that two cycles ago.”

“I don’t understand.”

“You wouldn’t. You see I’ve been here for the last two repeats. It’s taken me that long to set everything up. To learn everything I needed to know. Breaking the bonds I placed on Anna isn’t such a simple thing as you have probably long figured out. I made it difficult for even me to do. That’s why it took me so long to implement this plan.”

“It was you than wasn’t it! You are the reason everything is happening out of order!”

“Correct on the first try. I couldn’t completely break the chain of events. That would either destroy the world or reset it back to the beginning and accomplish nothing. So I had to work within the confines and rules of the world, simply forcing what was going to happen naturally to happen sooner. Remember what I once told you about how to alter an anime world without breaking it?”

“Start at the beginning. A small change can become a tidal wave by the end of it. Something as simple as moving a rock to the left by four inches so someone doesn’t trip over it in the first episode can turn into a building falling down in episode eight.”

“Very good. And that is exactly what I did. I’ve been following you and Anna since I got here. Making those miniscule changes that you never noticed. That turned into what you see today. It’s why Anna has been acting unusual. Right now she thinks she is an NPC remember. So she reacts as an NPC would. Unlike us she can’t adapt at the drop of a hat, her programming needs to be changed so to speak.”

“Then was that really you in the school building earlier?”

“Yes and no. That was me, but not the current me. It was the me of the last cycle.”

“What do you mean?”

“Time manipulation. It would be impossible for me to do everything I needed to do and be everywhere I needed to be. I am still just one person. But what if there were three of me? The me of this timeline, and the two me’s from the last two cycles? Then I would be able to easily jump in and out of all the places I needed to be without any problems.”

“But how is that possible?”

“Technology has advanced quite a bit in the last four years you have been in here. Especially rift technology. Time travel devices are still highly experimental and only work effectively in worlds that have magic like this one, but the ability is still there. Now I am sure you have a lot more questions but they can wait. Hurry up and get cleaned up, I need your help for the last part of my plan. Lexi is following Anna for now so you can rest easy on that point. But if you want her to get her memories back you need to hurry up and help me.”

“What’s going to happen after that?”

“Well I guess it sort of depends on her doesn’t it? I’m willing to let her leave this reality and go back to growing up. Give her the chance to grow older and have kids. You two can work out your relationship or not, since I really don’t know what her mind will be like after this. For all I know she could still be crazy or even farther over the deep end than before. As long as she stays away from me and my family I’m willing to let her be.”

He pulled out a package of steak from the freezer as I turned to head to the bathroom. I could hear him begin to hum even as I left the room. Things were looking up and beginning to make a lot of sense again. It was no wonder I hadn’t been able to control things like I usually did, I had been up against the very person who had taught me everything I knew. With a smile creeping onto my lips I turned on the shower, pulling off my disguise ring as I stepped inside. Letting the cold soothing liquid soak into my rubbery skin, the suckers on my four tentacles finally opening up to breath now that I was back in real water.

*********

“Are you sure this is going to work uncle Chris?”

“Mostly sure.”

“How much is mostly?”

“Hmm. About ninety seven percent mostly? No. ninety eight definitely mostly.”

“And the other two percent?”

“We restart this all over again and think up a new plan.”

“Right, then this has to work.”

It felt good working with uncle Chris again. Not like during the Oglian war, but this more personal touch. Like when he had brought me into the Anime Realities for the first time and showed me the ropes. How to pick locks and make the world bend to my will. How to create something out of nothing both with and without magic.

I had missed his sense of humor. The way he could make even the most dire situation seem funny. Or the way he knew just when to put in that bit of sarcasm to lighten the mood. How he could make anything he did look cool, even something as simple as drinking a cup of coffee. I wanted to be just like him. Wanted to have that same kind of air about me. I knew I had a long way to go. And I would probably never be a match for him. But I still wouldn’t stop trying. Because even after everything was said and done, he was my hero.

It was evening now and Anna was inside the supermarket getting food for evening dinner with Billy. It was still hard for me to think of her as Anna again after I had thought and called her Chel for so long. It was the same difficult transition I had made when I had first come to this Reality to protect her. Only at that time it had been in the opposite direction. I could just make out aunt Lexi’s shadowed form standing on the side of the store waiting for her daughter to come out.

Even through the store window Anna looked like a dead person walking. As if all the life had been sucked out of her. Each step she took seemed to be automatic more than anything else. I had seen this kind of look before. It was the look of someone who had lost the will to live but had not yet come to the point of taking their own life. Billy took her by the hand as if she were the younger of the two of them, leading her out of the store. Uncle Chris patted me on the back to let me know it was my turn. With a deep breath I twisted my ring to drop my disguise as I stepped out of the shadows.

I knew I must look like a monster to them, like an octopus head on a mans body. With four tentacles instead of normal arms. Three eyes blinking rapidly over a small beak and skin a pale orange color. To give him credit, Billy stepped in front of his sister with shaking knees. I tried to smile reassuringly at the boy, forgetting that in this form he would only see me clacking my beak.

“Anna. It’s me. It’s time to go home now. It’s time for the dream to end. You don’t have to suffer anymore.”

“Ge-get back you freak! Stay away from my sister!”

Anna blinked at me over the boys head, her eyes staring blankly. Finally a little life came into them as she took a slow step forward.

“C-Chris…Cri’sa?”

I nodded my head as I reached out and laid my left tentacle against her face.

“It’s me. And you’re finally back. Now we need to leave before this world restarts. We can explain things later.”

“B-but…”

“Later.”

Uncle Chris stepped out of the shadows where he was hiding, pulling what looked like a pocket book out of his pants and hitting a few buttons on it. The fabric of reality next to me split open as aunt Lexi started towards us as well. I held out my tentacle to Anna who was still looking confused.

“Come with me Anna. Let me take you out of here. Let’s really live our lives this time.”

She hesitated only briefly before taking my outstretched hand and allowed me to pull her into the rift with me. Uncle Chris and aunt Lexi were only a few steps behind.

“Sigh. So now you know the truth. Or at least part of it. I knew this time would come eventually. It was entertaining having them both here with me. I remember when that man brought them here almost sixty cycles ago. Asked me to watch over them.”

“Hmm? What’s that? Oh yes I knew we were all fictional from the start. Always have. I’m a god remember. Even if I am a made up fictional god. Still I get bored, especially when I am the only one who remembers time after time with each reset.”

“Would you like to go back in time with me? I’ll let you keep your memories. We can jump through someone else’s memories and see this course of events from every angle. When you finally get bored and you understand everything I will let time resume its normal course. We can go back to doing our usual routine.”
1112111211.title: Now who is this!

111211122.content:
“NOOOOOOOOOO!”

“Sis… come on we need to get going. I don’t know what is going on but big brother Chris told me to get home and not leave. I think he was right. I have a feeling things are going to get bad really soon.”

I felt his hand tugging on mine and let him lead me away. I couldn’t stop the tears from flowing. He was dead. Blown into little bits. Why had he gone into the school? Why hadn’t he left with Billy?

The world passed me in a blur. It was all just random noises and flashing moments of darkness and light. It was over. Everything was over. Chris wouldn’t be there in the mornings to greet me. Or make witty one liners with his dry sarcastic voice. He wouldn’t be there to play along with my flights of fancy, or make me feel safe when I was scared.

I wouldn’t hear him tell me that he loved me anymore or see him glancing at me sideways when he thought I wasn’t looking. All the normal days were gone in an instant. Destroyed along with the school. He had somehow known all about this. Somehow he knew it was going to happen. He had been telling me goodbye before. Back before he had left me at the church. I had just been too stupid to realize it.
