I must have hurt his feelings because he hunched his shoulders a bit, sticking his hands in his pockets and trying to look as unthreatening as possible. But he had the same feel as Chris did. That sense that even though he looked mean on the outside, he was nice on the inside. I felt like I could trust him. So I swallowed once and nodded my head at his question.

“Yeah I’m lost. And I forgot my cell phone at home. Some guys chased me and I just ran. I lost my shoes someplace and I tripped while running. I finally lost them but I don’t know where I am.”

“Do you live around here? If so I could walk you home. I know this area pretty well.”

Chris had said not to trust people too easily, but I just wanted to go home. If he was willing to help me then I would accept his help. If he meant to harm me there was nothing I could do. And to top it all off it was beginning to rain lightly.

“113 East Lancer Street.”

He nodded quickly before sitting down on the bench next to me and slipping off his sneakers and handing them to me. I tried to protest but he wouldn’t hear any of it.

“They might be a little big but at least it will cover your feet. Your street isn’t too far away. About a twenty minute walk. I’ve got a friend that lives over that way so I know the general area.”

He stripped off his shirt as well and handed it to me to use as a makeshift umbrella. When I opened my mouth to tell him he didn’t need to he shushed me.

“It’s not that cold out and I’m not bothered by it. I’m built to not get colds. You know the saying, stupid don’t catch colds.”

“You’re not stupid.”

“Yes I am. I know it. It’s just the way I was born.”

“Won’t your feet get cold and wet?”

“Probably. But better my feet get wet then your’s. You look like the type that catches a cold easily.”

“Well you are right kind of, I do catch colds more often then other people.”

“See?”

His shoes were really large on my feet, I felt like a clown in them. They clopped along on the wet cement and I had to push my feet back into them every few steps. But I was still secretly glad to have them. I didn’t want to walk home in wet cold socks.

“What’s your name anyway?”

“I’m Chelsea Winters.”

“Richard Noel. Pleasure to meet you. So any particular reason you were out so late?”

“Not really.”

“Ah, I know that tone. Boy trouble I bet.”

“How’d you know?”

“I’m psychic. Actually been on the other side with some girl trouble of my own just recently. My friend helped me out of it. Want to tell me about it? Perhaps I can pass the favor on. You don’t know me and I don’t know you. Sometimes it’s easier to talk to a near stranger about this kind of stuff.”

I was silent for a moment but then hesitantly told him.

“This might sound kind of pathetic, but there is this boy that confessed to me and I shot him down. But he is still my friend and acts like nothing has happened. I don’t want things to change between us, but my parents keep pushing me to get together with him. One of my girlfriends said she is going to make a move on him but I don’t want that either. We got into a bit of an argument tonight while he was over at my place and he kissed me out of the blue. I didn’t know what else to do so I ran out the door. I just kept running and ended up lost.”

“Sounds to me like a part of you wants to be his girlfriend. Otherwise you wouldn’t be so adverse to another girl taking him. I’m not an expert on relationships. My friend is better at this stuff then I am. But I don’t think it is wrong to want to just stay friends. I mean sure I would feel hurt if I confessed my feelings to someone and got rejected, but I wouldn’t see that as a reason to stop being friends with them either. If that was what she really wanted I would learn to accept that and move on. I mean guys and girls can have a relationship without dating.”

“But it sounds like you don’t want to move on. You want to keep things in stasis so you don’t have to make any decisions. I’m not saying that’s wrong, but I don’t think it is completely right either. It’s unfair both to you and to him. I can’t say why he kissed you either, but that sort of tells me that he still likes you and isn’t completely content with being just a friend.”

His thoughts on the matter all seemed to make sense. They helped me sort out my own confused thoughts and emotions a little and put them in perspective. After he said his piece he was content to simply walk along in silence. I was thankful to that because I wanted to think. Finally things started looking familiar right before we turned into the residential area.

“Thanks for trying to help me. Oddly I feel better now. You’re right, I really need to think about what I want. I never thought that I was being unfair to him before. Despite what you say, you’re pretty smart. A dumb person wouldn’t have been able to talk like that.”

“Thanks. But it doesn’t take brains to have a bit of common sense and just speak your mind. But I will take your compliment with grace.”

It wasn’t long before we were finally home. I returned his clothes to him and offered to let him come in and dry off but he shook his head. Saying he had to get home as well. I gave him one last wave as he left the yard and headed back the way we had come. I watched him disappear into the darkness for a moment before closing the door on the night.
11321.title: Ignore the Rift

choices: Follow the mystery man through the door
11322.content:
"No matter how many times we do this it still makes me feel a bit queasy. I suppose being ripped out of the present and flung into the past or future through someone else's power does that to even a god like me. It's no wonder you got turned inside out that one time."

"Oh wait... I probably shouldn't have said that should I? Oh no worries, it only happened once. I'm sure it was just a freak thing. Too much gas inside or something. Anyways, forget all that. We made it and the rift is still open. Let's see what we can see shall we?"

I knew this day would come. I knew it from the very first moment. Lexi was nothing if not persistent. Still I had thought it would take her another few years at least. Unless someone told her where to find Anna. I didn't want to believe that though. Only three other people knew where I had dumped her and one of them opted to stay with her because he loved her. Lenna and Fan'sul were the other two. Because Lenna was my wife and Fan' was Cri'sa's father. But I trusted them both with my life. I would hope neither one would betray my trust in them.

Manipulation. I felt that's all I ever did anymore. Ever since I had destroyed not only an entire species of alien but their very planet as well. That was the point when everything just got worse. I had been embroiled in intergalactic politics for a solar system not even my own. Because I was akin to a god to all those alien people. A god in the Anime Realities and a god in real life. I had toppled empires and saved planets. Ended disputes and solved seemingly unsolvable problems for them. In their minds it was only right that I help lead them into a better future. An unofficial adviser on the United Planetary Forces.

Now I was going to use that skill in manipulation again. This time to help a woman I had once loved intimately, and a part of me still loved, get back a daughter who had gone a bit crazy. A daughter that had tried to humiliate, rape and murder my own little girl. I had vowed that I would kill both of them if I ever saw them again. I knew I had it in me to do so. I had killed for less in the years I had lived. Yet I had hesitated when I saw her again. Lexi wasn't my enemy. Not really. She was just a parent like me. A woman who had become a bit mentally unstable after her husband died. I knew minds could crack from less stress.

So now it was time to play god one more time. To give back the memories I had stolen to a girl that could very well go after my daughter again. If that happened I would have no choice but to kill her. And then her mother when she turned on me. Perhaps even Cri'sa because I killed the woman he loved.

But I had to work from the shadows. I couldn't be spotted. Not by Cri'sa, and not by Anna. I couldn't be tied to anyone or anything. If I was I wouldn't be able to break down the interconnected chain of events to the point that the world couldn't repair itself and compensate for the glitches I created.

I idly scratched the skin under my right eye, the eye patch beating gently against the back of my hand as I inserted the key into the door with my left. Well I had best get to work now, laying the foundations before the story started over.

"The Time warp is collapsing! We need to get out of here now! I found us an anchor point back in the present. It's only a small time jump forward, we won't end up exactly where we left the time line at but it was the best I could do. Hey, this isn't an exact science even for a god you know! Manipulating things through someone else's rifts is pretty difficult! I'd like to see you do a better job! I do wonder what he meant by Anime Realities though. Still while interesting it seems to have nothing to do with our world. I mean he didn't even look like the guy Yushihito was talking to! Wait... yes, that was the timeline time rift we came from. Whew no spoilers for you!"
11322.title: You only live once! Let's jump!

113221.content:
"You are crazy you know that! Crazy with a capital C-R-A-Z-Y! Fine let's follow him. But whatever happens this is your fault not mine."

With a sigh I opened the door and saw a normal enough town. A world where gods once existed and still did. Where people had diluted powers of ancient heroes, angels and demons. A world and a city in the middle of a war. Buildings in flames and buildings collapsing. I felt a presence and looked around quickly. No one was there though. With a shrug I stepped through the door.
113221.title: Follow the mystery man through the door

113222.content: "Oh joy another anchor point popped up! Well which one do you chose Kimo Sabi?"
113222.title: Let's get out of here

choices: I'm tired of following these two, let's find someone else
12.content:
“Oh. I see. Interesting choice. Are you sure you want to follow her? Are you sure you shouldn’t have found out what Chris was up to? She doesn’t seem very interesting. Well you are the one with the power here. I’m just the disembodied voice offering a little advice here and there. We could always rewind time and do the choice over before it is too late. Oh wait, never mind, I didn’t give you that power. Well no help for it, you made your choice so lets see what Chel the free spirit is up to.”

“That will be twelve dollars and fifty three cents please.”

I absently pulled fifteen dollars from my wallet and handed it to the cashier, dropping the change back inside when he handed it to me. Picking up the bag of vegetables I headed out the door. Would Chris really come tonight or would he plead some excuse again? What was his problem anyway? Always so broody and going off to do things without telling me. Didn’t he know I worried about him?

Especially since he lived all alone in that house of his. With his mom gone all the time for her work and his dad dead or off who knows where it had to be lonely for him. He put on that tough guy face but I knew deep down he wanted to be a part of a family. That’s why he always came alive when he came over to our house. He had a surrogate mom and dad and even a little brother to play with. Though would I be his older sister or his younger? My birthday was before his but he treated me more like a younger sister then older.

My pocket vibrated as my phone went off. It took me a moment of juggling to transfer one of the bags to the other hand but I was finally able to dig it out and answer it before I missed the call.

“Hey girlfriend! What’cha up to?”

“Hey Tina. Nothing’ much, just buying a few groceries for dinner tonight.”

“Listen, I got this guy I think will be perfect for you. You interested?”

“Sorry, not interested.”

“What’s the problem? You already shot Chris down didn’t you? It’s all over the school you know. How you friend zoned him like it was nothing. Don’t know why he still hangs with you after something like that. But I like that about him. I been thinking of going after him myself. Thought this might be a great time for a double date.”

My insides went cold and the light carefree feeling I had in my chest suddenly turned into a solid ice block. What did she know anyway? Things weren’t that simple.

“I’m not interested and neither is he.”

I hung up on her and shut my phone off before she had a chance to reply. Angrily I stuffed the phone back into my pocket. She was right though. If I were Chris I probably wouldn’t have stuck around me either after being rejected. But I didn’t want things to change between us. I had fun with him and I felt comfortable. He made me feel safe. If I were to go out with him things would just be weird. It would be like dating my own brother. It was easier to just think of him that way. Easier to not think of him as a boy really.

Deep down I felt I didn’t deserve to go out with him. I wasn’t big into past life mumbo jumbo, but this feeling of unease; like I had hurt him deeply in another life, came over me when I thought of him romantically. Things were fine the way they were. Nothing had to change. As long as nothing changed we would always be happy.

My free hand began to tremble for no real reason and I pulled it into my chest to clutch my shirt. Everything was going to be fine. Chris would come over to the house and we would have fun. He would roughhouse and play games with my little brother and my mom would whisper hints that I should get together with him that I would ignore or misunderstand. It would be a normal visit. Then tomorrow I would walk to school with him and act like a kid like I always did. Making up some off the wall story to something he said and enjoying the back and forth we were used to.

There was nothing wrong with any of that. We didn’t need to start dating. He was fine with our arrangement as well. He wouldn’t have stayed my friend or acted like nothing had happened if he wasn’t. But no one else could have him either. No one would take him away from me. Would keep us from having our normal days together. **** Tina for bringing that up anyway! Couldn’t she just leave well enough alone? Couldn’t she mind her own business?

Calm down Chelsea. Don’t get worked up. It’s not worth it. Nothing is wrong. Everything is fine. Chris doesn’t know and he will never know. He will be the same as always. When he knocks on the door he will probably have a cake, he will grin and say something like honey I’m home in a joking manor. I will throw myself at him and he will catch me as I wrap my arms around his neck playfully. That’s how it always went when he came over. That’s how it would go today. Tina’s words wouldn’t change that. So just stay calm Chel.

“It seems our carefree girl isn’t so carefree. Isn’t it interesting how such misunderstandings happen because humans don’t speak to one another? It is one of the many reasons I was entertained for so long. At first you mortals were incomprehensible to me. But slowly over the eons as I studied you and observed you I came to understand just a bit how your minds work.”

“Not completely mind you. But a bit. You all have your own reasons for acting the way you do. Not that they always make much sense to me. But hey, that’s why I am a god and not a human. But looking into her mind with you I find it even more odd indeed. There is a blockage. As if someone had suppressed her memories. Perhaps she is suppressing them herself. I can’t get past the block to see deeper unless I break it completely. But I will not do that, I am still mainly an observer. All I can get is brown eyes. The same brown eyes Chris was thinking about after taking care of the punks. Curiouser and curiouser.”

“Oh wait you don’t know anything about that do you? You can’t see down the multiple paths at the same time like I can. Hmm, I need to get better at this. It’s been a long time since I dealt with a mortal. The last time was what, almost two thousand years ago in Israel? I keep forgetting how limited your minds are. I need to keep that in mind so as not to hurt your brain too much. Ah well enough of my meandering! Back to the story!”

Opening the front door I was greeted by the soothing sounds of water running in the kitchen down the hall to the right and the TV running in the living room to the left. The sound of pounding feet upstairs told me Billy had one of his friends over. I slipped my shoes off and headed to the kitchen with my groceries. My mom gave me a smile as I unloaded my bounty, washing my hands before picking up a knife and helping her make dinner.

“Chris said he was going to come over tonight to eat if that’s ok with you.”

“Of course it is sweetie. You know we always love having him over. The poor boy probably doesn’t get many good meals. Because we all know men can’t cook, that’s a special skill only us women have perfected.”

She chuckled a bit at her joke and I grinned back.

“Don’t let him hear you say that or he might try to prove you wrong. And he would probably succeed too. I’ve tasted his cooking and I’m not ashamed to admit it is worlds better then mine.”

“That just means you need to get that much better then doesn’t it honey? Win over a man’s heart by winning over his stomach. That’s what my mother always said. And it’s true too. It’s how I won your father. So when are you going to finally admit the truth and start going out?”

“We are just friends mom. Just really good friends. Like brother and sister. He’s happy with the way things are now and so am I.”

“And pigs fly. I’ve seen the way he looks at you. I know you don’t like to talk about it and you don’t like me harping on it. But sweetie, that boy likes you. I heard he even asked you out and you rejected him. Yet he still sticks around. That’s love right there. You might be happy with the way things are but I bet he isn’t. Take it from someone who knows honey. If you keep waiting around expecting things to stay the same he is eventually going to get tired of waiting and be snatched up by someone else. When he does you will realize how you really feel and it will be too late.”

I continued chopping up vegetables in silence and my mom thankfully dropped the subject. I lost myself in my work. Feeling a few tears beginning to threaten, I pulled an onion over and began to cut. Using it as an excuse to let my eyes water. Why was I even crying? I never understood when these sudden bouts came over me. It didn’t last long, it never did, so I was able to get over it by the time I was finished with the onion.

When the doorbell rang and my dad answered it I heard Chris out in the hall making his regular joke just like I had expected. But I couldn’t find it in me to go greet him like I normally did. I heard pounding feet as Billy came downstairs at a run.

“Bro!”

I imagined Chris ruffling his hair as Billy grinned up at him, joy written all over his fourteen year old face. The pit in my stomach came back suddenly and wouldn’t leave.
12.title: Follow Chel!

121.content:
I heard the muffled sounds of them talking out in the hall moments before mom set her knife down and headed out to join them, leaving the door open slightly so I could hear the conversation clearly.

“Chel is finishing up in the kitchen dear. Dinner will be ready in about an hour.”

“Sweet! Then you can help us with our homework right? And then we can play Splat after dinner!”

I heard the creaking of the steps as Chris went upstairs with Billy and his friend, saying he couldn’t promise any games after dinner. I knew he would make some time to play with my brother though. He always protested like that and he always ended up in a game or two. Secretly I was glad. I didn’t want to deal with him right now. I felt that if I did, everything would change. I didn’t know how it would change but I knew it would. I was regretting inviting him over. But it was too late to tell him to go home. I just needed to get through tonight and things could go back to normal in the morning.

Mom came back in and picked up her knife again without a word. That didn’t last long though, only long enough for her to cut a potato.

“I can finish up in here. Why don’t you go spend time with Chris.”

“No. I’ll let Billy have some time with him. It’s not often that he comes over and I see him every day.”

She began cutting another potato as I filled a pot with water.

“Two months.”

“What?”

“That’s the running bet I have with the other wives. I told them he would only wait around for two months before finally giving up and looking for another girl. Nelly from down the street thinks he will wait on you forever, but she is the only one. Some thought he would only wait a week at the most, and the longest one aside from Nelly’s prediction is six months. But I think I know that boy pretty well, and I’m pretty sure you only have about another two months the way things stand. I’m not trying to be pushy, but I don’t want you to get hurt sweetie. You two need to work something out. Otherwise something’s going to burst.”

She handed me a few cans of pop and pointed at the door.

“You should at least go offer them something to drink. It’s only good manners.”

With a sigh I left the safety of the kitchen and headed upstairs. I heard mumbling from the closed door as I walked closer. I was about to knock when I heard what they were talking about. The voices becoming much clearer. Chris was giving my brother advice on how to treat a girl and how to talk to them. I could imagine my brother sitting in rapt attention. My brother asked him another question and Chris answered him in all seriousness.

“Listen. If there is a person you like then you should just go for it. There will never be a perfect moment or a best opportunity. You can try to set it up, like I did when I confessed to your sister to make it a bit more romantic, but things happen. Words get caught in your throat, they don’t say the words or ask the questions you imagined they would, the timing is off. If you are thinking they are perfect then it won’t work out. If you are holding off for that perfect woman the same is true. People are flawed. you have to accept that. Even if you ask a girl out you barely know you have to expect they are flawed and not get angry or disappointed when they don’t live up to your imagination. All you can do is tell them you like them and hope for the best.”

“But doesn’t it feel weird being around my sister after she said no?”

Chris didn’t answer right away like I thought he would. I was afraid to hear the answer so turned away before he spoke up. I went into my room and dropped the drinks on the desk before heading back downstairs. I busied myself with cleaning the dishes for the remainder of the time until dinner was served.

I kept my eyes down and tried not to look at him all through dinner. The pit in my stomach wouldn’t go away and only seemed to get worse every time I snuck a peek at him.

“This is good Mrs. W. Been a while since I had hamburger steak.”

“Please how many times have I told you to call me mom. I mean you’re practically family anyway.”

“But I’m not family yet so I don’t feel right calling you mom.”

I could almost feel the eyes on me as everyone waited for me to say the expected denial. So I did. The words feeling like lead in my throat. My heart just wasn’t in it right now, but no one seemed to notice.

“He’s never going to be family so you should just drop it mom.”

As soon as dinner was over I made a beeline for my room and closed myself in. Behind that small amount of safety I slid to the floor and let out a sigh of relief. So far so good. I could do this. Give him a few moments to cloister himself away in my brothers room and then I could slip out the door and into the night until he left. I could apologize to him later if he even said anything. If he even noticed I was gone.

Once I gained a bit of confidence I dug through my dresser quickly, tearing off my school skirt and replacing it with a slightly longer one. I threw a light blue sweater on over a plain white t-shirt after replacing my school button up blouse. Listening at the door a moment I couldn’t hear any noise. But he had to be in Billy’s room by now. As quietly as I could I slipped out of the room and headed for the stairs. I started in surprise as Chris met me coming up. I looked at the ground as I moved to go past him but he grabbed me by the arm.

“What’s up with you Chel?”

“Nothing.”

“Don’t give me that line of bull. You’ve been avoiding me since I got here. You were the one who
invited me over remember? You haven’t been acting at all like yourself. So spill it. What’s wrong?”

Why did he have to be so perceptive over the oddest things? Why couldn’t he just drop it like he normally did when I wanted him to? I pulled my arm out of his light grip and tried to get past him again without answering, simply telling him to drop it. But his hand shot out and planted itself against the wall to bar my way. I could have ducked under it but I knew he would continue to stop me.

“Not good enough. I’ve known you too long and there is something bugging you. Is it something I said or did? Somebody threaten you? Tell me. I have this uneasy pit in my stomach and I can’t just let this drop.”

“Just leave me alone already!”

“I can’t leave you alone! I’m your friend Chel!”

Something inside of me burst. The pit in my stomach seemed to rear up and engulf me and I couldn’t help raising my voice a little.

“But you don’t want to be right! You want to be more and I don’t! Everybody wants us to be more. Always saying we should hook up. Making offhand comments about how you are part of the family! It never stops! That’s the problem! Why don’t you all just drop it! I bet you are still acting like my friend because you think it will help you get in my pants!”

He slapped me across the face before I could say anything else. It hadn’t been hard but it still stung. It was the first time I could think of he had hit me. My eyes widened a bit in shock as I stared at him.

“Stop talking right there. I like you. I won’t deny that. You saying you didn’t want to go out didn’t suddenly change that fact. But I’m happy being your friend if that’s all you want. I’ll get over you eventually and I will find someone else. But that doesn’t change the facts. Whether we date or not you are still my friend.”

“You hit me!”

“And I’ll do it again if you keep talking stupid like that.”

I hunched my shoulders a bit and looked away. I felt my lips moving as they mumbled a few words on their own. I hadn’t meant to utter them. But after hearing him talk to my brother about girls they had just come out. Even I wasn’t sure if I had spoken them.

“I bet you don’t even love me anyway.”

Before I even knew what was happening he had grabbed me up by the shoulders and his lips were pressed against mine. I didn’t know what to do. My body simply stiffened in shock. The moment seemed to go on forever until he pulled away and stared at me so intently.

“That is how much I love you. Even if you forget it I never will.”

I felt like a fish out of water. My mouth opening and closing just a fraction. I didn’t know what to do or how to respond. Should I slap him? Should I yell at him? Before I knew what I was doing my feet had already taken me down the steps. I had my shoes on and was out the door before my mind finally caught up to me. I needed to get away. I needed to think. So I ran. And all the while the pit in my stomach grew bigger and bigger.

“Oh yeah, things just got steamy up in here. This Chris is a regular smooth operator. A little rough around the edges but give him a few years and he could have all the women falling for him. I really want to see what happens to him next. But I also want to know what Chel is thinking. Ok, that’s a bit of a lie, I already know what they are both thinking, but you don’t. I can’t give away too much as long as you are around. So I am trying to act more human for you. So you can identify with me more. Is it working? Well what will you choose?”
121.title: Dinner with Chel

122.content:
The door opened only seconds after I rang the doorbell. Mr. Winters greeted me like a long lost son like he always did and ushered me into the house. I grinned at him as I slipped my shoes off and stepped up into the main hall.

“Honey! I’m Home!”

Mr. Winters chuckled at my usual exclamation. I was expecting Chel to come out like she normally did and try to glomp me. Then we would banter back and forth a moment or two and we would all move on with the evening.

Bur Chel didn’t appear. That was odd. It had never happened before. Billy did come running down the steps though, launching himself from the lest step to squeeze me around the waist.

“Bro!”

I ruffled his hair as he grinned up at me. He was pretty tall at fourteen, though he had yet to go through a growth spurt. His head coming up barely to the middle of my chest. Another set of pounding feet on the stairs a moment later and another boy was standing in front of me.

“Bro, this is Sam, a friend from school. Sam this is Chris. He isn’t really my brother but he’s cool.”

He put his hand next to his mouth and whispered loud enough so everyone could hear.

“He likes my sister. It’s only a matter of time until he becomes my brother for real.”

“I think your sister might have something to say about that squirt.”

“You’ll win her over. And I’ll help. Just tell me what you want me to do.”

I ruffled his hair again as we shared a conspiratorial wink as Mrs. Winters came out of the kitchen wiping her hands. She smiled when she saw me as well, opening her arms and inviting me into a hug which I accepted. Everything else was normal about this visit, so why did I feel so uneasy all of a sudden?

“Chel is finishing up in the kitchen dear. Dinner will be ready in about an hour.”

“Sweet! Then you can help us with our homework right? And then we can play Splat after dinner!”

Billy began tugging on my arm and pulling me upstairs and I let him. I didn’t mind helping with homework but I told him we would have to see about video games afterwards. He didn’t seem to hear me but that wasn’t unusual.

Before I knew it I was in his room sitting on his bed while him and Sam plopped down in chairs at his desk. But instead of starting into the papers in front of him he swung around to face me, pulling his feet up onto the seat as well.

“I heard you confessed to sis and she shot you down.”

“I heard you wanted me to help you with your homework.”

“Pfft. I don’t need no help. This stuff is easy. I just wanted to hear the dirt on your confession.”

“Little busybody aren’t you?”

“Come on tell me please? Maybe give me some tips on what to do? Or not to do?”

“What? Got your eyes on someone?”

“Maybe.”

So I told him how it happened. How I had gone with the standard confession in an empty classroom after school. And her just as quick reply. He asked a few questions and I answered as best I could. From the direction of his questions he did have someone he liked and wanted to ask out. I finally just told him to go for it. There was no “perfect” time and place. If he waited to say anything it would end up being too late.

“Dinner’s ready!”

I glanced at the door in surprise. Had it really been an hour already? I always seemed to lose track of time while I was here. Everyone just made me feel like I belonged when I came over here. But I couldn’t forget myself. Couldn’t get too comfortable. I had to keep my distance if I wanted to keep Chel from getting hurt.

Only half my mind was on my surroundings as I followed Billy down the steps and into the dining room. The other half was mulling over the uneasiness that kept growing inside of me. Chel hadn’t even come upstairs to say hi. She might have been busy with dinner but she would have normally found time to see me, if even for a moment. This wasn’t how things were supposed to be. Had something happened between the time I had left her until now? Had I somehow done something to upset her?

“Pass the potatoes please.”

After handing over the bowl I cut another piece of meat off and stuck it in my mouth. Why wouldn’t she look me in the eyes? In fact she seemed to act like I wasn’t even here. This was not how it was supposed to be. I needed to get to the bottom of this. Needed to fix this somehow. But I couldn’t worry anyone else. I could already see them all looking sideways at me because I was so silent. I wasn’t acting normal either.

“This is good Mrs. W. Been a while since I had hamburger steak.”

“Please how many times have I told you to call me mom. I mean you’re practically family anyway.”

“But I’m not family yet so I don’t feel right calling you mom.”

“He’s never going to be family so you should just drop it mom.”

Chel’s reply, while more like her normal retort lacked the usual vibrancy and cheerfulness she usually had. I dropped the subject and simply finished eating, having a bit of small talk but otherwise keeping quiet. Once dinner was over I helped clear the table before helping Mrs. Winter wash dishes. She shooed me away after only a moment, saying it was her job not mine. That I was a guest. I feigned being hurt by her words but left her to her own devices when she giggled at my theatrics.

Heading upstairs I ran into Chel who looked away as she tried to slip past to go downstairs. I snagged her arm before she could go anywhere and forced her to look at me.

“What’s up with you Chel?”

“Nothing.”

“Don’t give me that line of bull. You’ve been avoiding me since I got here. You were the one who invited me over remember? You haven’t been acting at all like yourself. So spill it. What’s wrong?”

She pulled her arm out of my grasp. “I said nothing was wrong! Just drop it all right?”

When she again tried to slip past me I barred her path with a hand against the wall.

“Not good enough. I’ve known you too long and there is something bugging you. Is it something I said or did? Somebody threaten you? Tell me. I have this uneasy pit in my stomach and I can’t just let this drop.”

“Just leave me alone already!”

“I can’t leave you alone! I’m your friend Chel!”

“But you don’t want to be right! You want to be more and I don’t! Everybody wants us to be more. Always saying we should hook up. Making offhand comments about how you are part of the family! It never stops! That’s the problem! Why don’t you all just drop it! I bet you are still acting like my friend because you think it will help you get in my pants!”

I slapped her across the face before she could go on.

“Stop talking right there. I like you. I won’t deny that. You saying you didn’t want to go out didn’t suddenly change that fact. But I’m happy being your friend if that’s all you want. I’ll get over you eventually and I will find someone else. But that doesn’t change the facts. Whether we date or not you are still my friend.”

She reached up and rubbed her cheek while looking at me in surprise.

“You hit me!”

“And I’ll do it again if you keep talking stupid like that.”

“I bet you don’t even love me anyway.”

It was only a mumble but I heard it anyway as she looked away from me with downcast eyes. I couldn’t hold myself back anymore. My emotions were already high and those words were like a stab through the heart. I grabbed her shoulders suddenly, making her look at me in surprise. Before she could react I planted my lips on hers and pulled her in close. I could feel her rigid body in my arms as I tried to convey my feelings to her in that single kiss. Finally I pulled away and stared into her beautiful eyes.

“That is how much I love you. Even if you forget it I never will.”

She blinked at me a moment before tearing herself out of my embrace and running downstairs. I watched her push past her mom and dad who were looking up at us around the banister with grins on their faces. She ran to the door and slipped on her shoes before racing into the night.

I heard a creaking open behind me and turned in time to see Billy and Sam opening the bedroom door wider, their faces still peeking around the frame. When Billy noticed me looking at him he whistled and gave me a thumbs up sign.

“Aren’t you going to chase after her?”

“No. I said my piece. She needs time to be alone and sort it out herself. I don’t want to push her too much.”

“That’s my big brother, the ladies man. I want to be just like you when I grow up.”

“No you don’t. You have no idea how lucky you have it squirt.”

I headed downstairs to slipped on my shoes.

“I think it best if I go home now. I doubt she will want to see me when she gets back. Let her know I’m going to drop the matter. I know how she feels about me and I would like to go back to normal tomorrow. I didn’t mean to actually kiss her, but I’m not sorry I did.”

“You don’t see any of us complaining do you? Maybe that will wake her up and she will finally admit she likes you.”

I gave them a final parting wave before heading off down the street towards my house. Things were about to change. I could feel it in my bones.

“Oh yeah, things just got steamy up in here. This Chris is a regular smooth operator. A little rough around the edges but give him a few years and he could have all the women falling for him. I really want to see what happens to him next. But I also want to know what Chel is thinking. Ok, that’s a bit of a lie, I already know what they are both thinking, but you don’t. I can’t give away too much as long as you are around. So I am trying to act more human for you. So you can identify with me more. Is it working? Well what will you choose?”
122.title: Dinner with Chris

1221.content:
He kissed me! He kissed me! Why did he kissed me? Was I supposed to be happy or angry? I liked him but not like that right? What was I supposed to think? Things were changing and I couldn’t stop them. I didn’t want this. Didn’t want things to change. What was I supposed to do now? I couldn’t face him. I would say I was sick and stay home tomorrow. Yes that was reasonable. Missing one day of school wouldn’t be too bad. Or even two or three. I could just change schools entirely, that would fix everything. I just couldn’t face him right now. Maybe not ever.

I finally stopped running when my side began to hurt a bit. Looking around I didn’t recognize anything. This was the shopping district, I knew that much from the stores around me, but it wasn’t a part that I recognized. How had I gotten here exactly? I had simply taken turns blindly in my haste and now I was lost. Perhaps I should stay lost forever. Then I wouldn’t have to worry about facing Chris again.

That was stupid. Even if I wanted to, Chris would find me. He always found me when I was in real trouble. No matter how hard I tried to hide from him he would search for me and eventually find me. It was like he had a sixth sense. With a sinking dread I slowly turned around in a circle, trying to find some landmark I might recognize. Even if I could find a bus stop I could make it home eventually.

Nothing revealed itself though, so I sighed a bit before starting to walk in a random direction. I’d find something eventually. My phone! I could call home when I was ready and dad could come pick me up! Feeling a bit better about myself I slipped my hand in my pocket to clutch that lifeline.

It wasn’t there. I frantically checked every pocket but I didn’t have my phone on me. A quick flashback of changing and forgetting to pull my phone out of my school uniform zipped through my mind as the anxiety came back. I didn’t even have my wallet on me so I couldn’t even take a bus if I found one. Why was I so forgetful! Why did I have to leave everything at home now of all times?

I continued walking without a real clear direction, making random turns. Looking for a police officer to help me if nothing else. I noticed I was being followed by five boys as I was turning the corner. I hadn’t paid much attention to them to begin with but this was the fourth time they had turned where I had. I didn’t recognize any of them but they looked seedy. Chris had shown me how to spot troublemakers like this. I had thought he was just being overly paranoid at the time but now I was glad he had shown me.

When I turned another corner I started running. I didn’t care where I ran to, I just needed to put distance between me and them. That’s what Chris had told me to do. I might not know what to think about him right now but he had never given me bad advice before. I heard the shouts behind me as they turned the corner and saw me flying down the sidewalk dodging in and out of the crowd. As I took another corner I risked a glance back and saw them chasing me.

My ankle twisted a bit and I fell. An intense pain shot up my leg from where my knee scraped the cement. I could feel the wetness of blood as I stood up and continued to run. Their voices were louder now. I had lost a lot of ground by falling. I noticed the street light turning from red to green and ran out into the middle of the street to get to the other side. I knew it was foolish. Incredibly stupid and dangerous. Chris would have yelled at me for doing something like this if he was here.

Horns blared angrily but I made it across, putting a sea of vehicles between me and them. But I didn’t stop running. They were still to close. I rounded another corner and then ducked into an alley so I wasn’t on the main street. A hand shot out of a pile of boxes and grabbed my leg, making me shriek.

“Got any change?”

I shook my leg frantically, dislodging his hand but losing my shoe in the process. I didn’t care. I needed to get out of here. So I ran to the other end of the alley and into the next street. My running was lopsided with only one shoe so I pulled the other one off and tossed it away. Intent only on getting to safety. I was blinded in my panic, I knew that. All I saw was flashing lights and blurs of color. Sometimes a person as I bumped into them and slowed down, sometimes hearing an angry comment to watch out.

I stopped when my side began to hurt again. I was no great runner. I didn’t have much stamina. I was just scared. It had been stupid to just leave like that. To just run wildly from the house in the first place. I was stupid. Looking around I found I was standing in front of a bus stop bench with clear plastic walls and a roof. I sat down dejectedly, not even caring if those boys found me. I was lost, tired, hurt, and stupid. I wanted Chris to come save me. Even if he kissed me again I wanted him to find me like he always did and take me home. I covered my face as the tears began to fall.

“So, What’s the matter girl? You lost or somethin’?”

Chris had found me! I was so glad that he was here. I turned to yell at him for not finding me sooner and my voice caught in my throat. It wasn’t Chris. I didn’t even know this guy. He stood at almost six and a half feet tall and looked like someone had condensed down a building and stuffed it under his skin. He had a bit of a mean look on his face as his deep inset black eyes watched me. I instinctively flinched back before I could stop myself.

I must have hurt his feelings because he hunched his shoulders a bit, sticking his hands in his pockets and trying to look as unthreatening as possible. But he had the same feel as Chris did. That sense that even though he looked mean on the outside, he was nice on the inside. I felt like I could trust him. So I swallowed once and nodded my head at his question.

“Yeah I’m lost. And I forgot my cell phone at home. Some guys chased me and I just ran. I lost my shoes someplace and I tripped while running. I finally lost them but I don’t know where I am.”

“Do you live around here? If so I could walk you home. I know this area pretty well.”

Chris had said not to trust people too easily, but I just wanted to go home. If he was willing to help me then I would accept his help. If he meant to harm me there was nothing I could do. And to top it all off it was beginning to rain lightly.

“113 East Lancer Street.”

He nodded quickly before sitting down on the bench next to me and slipping off his sneakers and handing them to me. I tried to protest but he wouldn’t hear any of it.

“They might be a little big but at least it will cover your feet. Your street isn’t too far away. About a twenty minute walk. I’ve got a friend that lives over that way so I know the general area.”

He stripped off his shirt as well and handed it to me to use as a makeshift umbrella. When I opened my mouth to tell him he didn’t need to he shushed me.

“It’s not that cold out and I’m not bothered by it. I’m built to not get colds. You know the saying, stupid don’t catch colds.”

“You’re not stupid.”

“Yes I am. I know it. It’s just the way I was born.”

“Won’t your feet get cold and wet?”

“Probably. But better my feet get wet then your’s. You look like the type that catches a cold easily.”

“Well you are right kind of, I do catch colds more often then other people.”

“See?”

His shoes were really large on my feet, I felt like a clown in them. They clopped along on the wet cement and I had to push my feet back into them every few steps. But I was still secretly glad to have them. I didn’t want to walk home in wet cold socks.

“What’s your name anyway?”

“I’m Chelsea Winters.”

“Richard Noel. Pleasure to meet you. So any particular reason you were out so late?”

“Not really.”

“Ah, I know that tone. Boy trouble I bet.”

“How’d you know?”

“I’m psychic. Actually been on the other side with some girl trouble of my own just recently. My friend helped me out of it. Want to tell me about it? Perhaps I can pass the favor on. You don’t know me and I don’t know you. Sometimes it’s easier to talk to a near stranger about this kind of stuff.”

I was silent for a moment but then hesitantly told him, condensing it down as best I could into just a few sentences. He walked along quietly, staring straight ahead as if deep in thought. Finally he gave a small grin and told me his thoughts on the matter. They all seemed to make sense. They helped me sort out my own confused thoughts and emotions a little and put them in perspective. After he said his piece he was content to simply walk along in silence. I was thankful for that because I wanted to think. Finally things started looking familiar right before we turned into the residential area.

“Thanks for trying to help me. Oddly I feel better now. You’re right, I really need to think about what I want. I never thought that I was being unfair to him before. Despite what you say, you’re pretty smart. A dumb person wouldn’t have been able to talk like that.”

“Thanks. But it doesn’t take brains to have a bit of common sense and just speak your mind. But I will take your compliment with grace.”

It wasn’t long before we were finally home. I returned his clothes to him and offered to let him come in and dry off but he shook his head. Saying he had to get home as well. I gave him one last wave as he left the yard and headed back the way we had come. I watched him disappear into the darkness for a moment before closing the door on the night.
1221.title: I can't leave Chel alone

12211.content:
“Sorry dear, Chelsea isn’t feeling all that well. It seems she came down with a slight cold last night. So she won’t be going to school today.”

“I understand Mrs. W. Make sure to let her know that I hope she gets better soon. Also to stay away from the church over on Peach for a few days. I heard they have a bit of an asbestos problem and are cleaning it up. I don’t want her breathing any of it in by accident.”

“I’ll make sure to let her know. Have a good day at school.”

Mom closed the door and I let out a sigh as I slid down the wall just out of sight. She came around the corner into the living room and looked down at me quietly for a moment before squatting in front of me.

“Are you sure you don’t want to go? It’s not to late and I am sure you could catch up with him.”

“No. I can’t face him right now. I just can’t. I’m still just so confused.”

“I’m sure you are. I’m sure getting kissed like that out of the blue could throw anyone off. Though you didn‘t seem to dislike it from where I was standing.”

“Just leave me alone for now mom please? I don’t know what I feel and I already know you approve of what he did even if you lie about it to try and make me feel better. I wouldn’t be surprised if you put him up to it.”

She gave me a slight nod as she stood up, putting her hand on my head before going off into the house to do whatever she did all day. I laid my head on my raised knees, unable to move for the moment. I had meant to go to school today, I really had. But when I had put my hand on the knob I just hadn’t been able to open the door. The thought of seeing Chris waiting there like he was every morning had terrified me. That’s why I had hid from him. Having my mom make such a lame excuse. I was sure he saw right through it. But he was willing to play along for my sake. Willing to give me time. That was all I needed was time.

Keep telling yourself that Chelsea and maybe you’ll believe it. I needed more than time. I needed to come to a decision. I needed to make up my mind one way or another what exactly it was I wanted. Figure out what kind of relationship I wanted to have with him. That Richard fellow from last night was right. This was unfair to him. To act like nothing happened and continue to hang all over him like I always did. I wasn’t taking his feelings into account, only worried about my own.

I wasn’t sure how long I sat there like that. An hour? Ten minutes? I just couldn’t seem to stand up and move. The pit in my stomach seemed to just weigh me down to much. An irrational fear of moving made my body tremble. I felt the lump in my throat and tears threatening one moment and then nothing the next. I was a royal mess. The phone rang, breaking me out of my thoughts and causing me to jump. I heard my mother answering it out in the hall and then a moment later she came into the room holding it out to me.

“It’s for you. One of your teachers at school checking up on you.”

I took the phone tentatively. Who would call to check up on me? Especially so soon? My mother walked away so I could talk in peace.

“H-Hello?”

“Good morning Chelsea.”

It was a male voice but I didn’t recognize it. I sorted through all my male teachers but this voice definitely didn’t match any of them.

“Who are you? You aren’t a teacher.”

“Who I am isn’t important. What is important is your answer to a simple question. Do you want to know the truth?”

“Know what truth? What are you talking about?”

“The truth about everything. About the world you live in, about where Chris goes and what he does when you aren’t around. Who he really is. The truth about your feelings for him. You will never figure out anything if all you do is sit around doing nothing.”

I was silent, unable to answer him. My fingers gripping the receiver hard enough to hurt. How did he know all this? Who was this person?

“If you want to know the truth then head over to the church on Peach street right now. You will get all your answers there.”

“But Chris said they were clearing out asbestos from that place.”

“And I am sure it was just as true as the fact that you are sick. The choice is yours to make. Go or not. If you are happy with the way things stand then do nothing. But if you don’t go you are going to lose something precious to you.”

“Something precious? Like what?”

“Deep down you already know the answer to that.”

There was a click on the other end moments before the dial tone began buzzing in my ear. I pulled the phone away and looked at it a bit stupidly, wondering if I could trust anything he had said. The call had been more than strange. Mom came back in then wiping her hands dry on her apron.

“That’s nice that your teacher was worried about you sweetie. Mr. Jones sounded like a very nice man. I hope I get to meet him at the school festival next week. My! That means the school year is coming to a close doesn’t it? Only two weeks after the festival and you will be home all day.”

She took the phone from my fingers before leaving me alone again. The truth huh. About this world, about Chris, about my feelings. Before I knew it I was pulling on my shoes and my hand was already opening the door.

“I’m going out for a bit Mom!”

“All right sweetie! Stay out of trouble and don’t stay out too late!”

I let the door close and took off at a jog towards Peach street. The church was actually on my normal route to school so I knew it would take about five minutes to get there at this pace. It wasn’t far from Billy’s middle school as well. Come to think about it, the church was pretty much in the center of the town. A stones throw away from many of the most important places, like the schools, the court house, even the police station. But for all of that why did it always seem abandoned?

I could see the tall steeple of the church rising up in front of me. I just needed to go down this road and make a left and I would be there. But before I could take more than another three steps a woman jumped out of the shadows and snatched me up I struggled to get free but she was holding on too tight.

“Don’t go there! I don’t know what he said to you but don’t go any farther! Stay away from that church!”

“But…!”

“Listen to me please! You have to trust me!”

“Who are you! I don’t even know you!”

“Oh baby! I’m sorry! I keep forgetting. This must be very frightening for you. Are you sure you don’t recognize me even a little?”

I shook my head back and forth quickly, too afraid to speak.

“It’s me, your mother. Please remember! Remember who I am…”

She cut off whatever she was about to say, looking over her shoulder quickly at Chris who was just turning the corner coming from the church. She let out a grunt of displeasure and grimaced before letting me go, running off down the street away from him. He jogged over to me in surprise and looked off at the fleeing woman.

“Who was that?”

“I don’t know. She said she was my mother.”

His eyes got a distant look to them as he stared more intently at the empty street where the woman had just been. He chewed his lower lip a moment as his eyes narrowed but he didn’t say anything else. Hesitantly I looked from him to the empty street and back before my curiosity became too great.

“Do you know her?”

“No… She just reminded me of someone I once knew. Anyways what are you doing here? I thought I told you not to come around the church for a bit.”

“I could ask you the same thing. What are you doing here? Shouldn’t you be in school?”

He gave me an offhand shrug. “I ditched. Just like you did. But that still doesn’t answer my question, why are you here?”

Before I could open my mouth the world tilted sideways and I found myself laying on the ground. My mind processed the fact that I had heard a loud booming noise, that was why my ears were ringing. I saw a tall column of flames and smoke rising into the air where the church steeple had stood moments before. Above me Chris was standing with braced feet staring up at the flames, his fist clenched tightly with a look that has hard to describe on his face. There was sadness and joy mixed in with a sense of knowing and perhaps a bit of madness. It was a face I had never seen him make before and I never wanted to see again.

“All right! A bit of senseless violence to start the day. I remember when I used to do things like that. Smite a heathen or two just for the fun of it. It really brightens the mornings. Makes the rest of the day feel extra special. It was really fun when I flung meteorites down on their cities. But I only did that once, and they deserved it. It really couldn’t be called interference at all really. The meteors were already going to hit the Earth. I just sort of … tweaked their trajectory a bit.”

“Ah, enough with the fond reminiscing. I’m sure you don’t want to hear sordid tales of my youth. You want to know about these fine people. So, what will it be? The bewildered damsel or the enigmatic man?”
12211.title: What about Chelsea?

122111.content:
For the first time since I could remember knowing him, I was afraid of Chris. That look on his face scared me like nothing else had. It just wasn’t right. There was something off about it. Like he was a bit insane while smiling like that.

As I got to my feet Chris turned at a slight sound behind us. When I looked as well I felt my jaw dropping in surprise. I pointed at the new person almost reflexively.

“You! You’re the guy from last night! Richard Noel right?”

“Aye. And you’re Chelsea Winters.”

“Wait, you two know each other?”

“Yeah he walked me home last night after… after dinner.”

“I didn’t know that trouble you were telling me about was Chris! If I had I would have given you better advice.”

“Like what you oversized muscle factory?”

“Like she should stay as far away from you as possible. That you are nothing but trouble.”

The two of them shook hands, grinning like fools. Seeming to be unconcerned that someone had just blown up the church. When Chris asked Richard why he was here, the big man glanced at me before pulling him off to the side to have a whispered conversation. I tried to make my ears grow so I could hear what they were saying without being obtrusive about it but all I heard was unintelligible mumbling.

Just who were these two anyway? That strange voice on the phone had been right. Chris was hiding something from me. Perhaps a lot of something’s. I didn’t know the truth about anything. I suddenly got this insight that I had been in the dark about everything. Living some sort of lie that Chris knew the truth about. Being happy in my ignorance while Chris lived a life I knew nothing about.

The two of them finally finished their conversation and Richard headed off away from us thanking Chris for his help and giving a wave. Chris waved back, calling after him in parting.

“No worries. And if I don’t see you again soon, keep safe and don’t die.”

“Back at you bro.”

I glanced up at the fire in fascination. Somehow I knew some of the answers that I wanted was right around the corner. All I had to do was take the few steps and get there. Chris broke me out of my reverie by shaking my shoulders. I looked at him a bit stupidly, trying to shake myself out of the trance those flames had put me under.

“Chel. I want you to go home. Run as fast as you can and don’t go outside for anything. For nothing you hear me! I don’t care if someone will grant your every wish if you just step outside. Don’t leave the house.”

“What about you?”

“Don’t worry about me. I’ll be fine. I’ll go get Billy out of school and send him home too. Something big is going down. I don’t know what but it is dangerous. I don’t want you getting hurt.”

“O-Ok. You’ll come home with Billy then right?”

“Of course. I’d hate to die and make you cry.”

I gave him a small nod. He was always trying to protect me. I should listen to him. He was worried about me. I turned to go but he held me back, his hand lingering on my arm. I looked back at him puzzled. Did he have something else he had forgotten to say?

“Chel. Always remember that I love you. For now and forever. No matter what happens.”

He turned and started jogging then, heading back towards the fire. Back towards the answers. I hesitated a moment before starting to run as well. Run after him like a fool. Turning the corner shortly after him I saw bodies littering the ground where they had been flung by the blast. Half charred and still smoking, both alive and dead. Some moaning, some screaming. Ahead of me Chris ran past them all. One of them shot out an arm and grabbed him, ask for help. I thought he would stop and help him, that was the kind of person he was.

Instead I watched horrified as he pulled a knife from behind his back. As he swung it downward the blade seemed to fold out into a sword which sliced clean through the mans arm at the elbow. He flicked it up, returning it to dagger size and shoving it back into the hidden place on his back he had taken it from and kept running without a backwards glance. I felt my hand rise to my mouth as bile rose in my throat, a scream threatening to erupt from my mouth. Chris shook the hand off his ankle absently as he picked up his pace a bit.

How could he do that! That wasn’t Chris. It couldn’t be. The Chris I knew was nothing like that. He was a bit of a trouble maker and got into a fight every now and again but he was a good guy. And what kind of weapon was that? I had never seen anything like that before. I hadn’t thought anything like that could exist.

Picking my way through the bodies, I tried not to throw up at the stench. I couldn’t let him out of my sight. I had to get to the bottom of this. I had to ask him exactly what was going on.

But he was fast. He was almost out of sight by the time I managed to maneuver through the road in front of the church. I knew where he was going though. He had told me he was going to get Billy and the middle school was at the end of this street. Running as hard as I could I finally came in sight of the walled in school, the white walls standing a towering eight feet in the air like an impenetrable barricade.

I was just in time to see him running up a tree trunk without using his hands. It looked like some sort of wire retracted into his belt when he flicked his arm. He didn’t hesitate to run along the branch and jump to the top of the wall within seconds of getting up the tree. He moved so fluidly, nothing like I had seen him move before. He had made scaling that wall seem effortless.

I ran over to the gate guard demanding to be let in. the guy looked at me like I was crazy as he asked for my name. I was about to give it to him when I noticed him starting to pick up the phone. He was going to call the police on me. I was supposed to be in school. I was playing hooky right now so he wanted my name to give to the authorities. I saw Chris running to the side of the building through the gate and I got angry.

“Just let me in god **** it! My friend is in there! He thinks something bad is going to happen and he is trying to save my brother! I don’t know what is going on but I think he is right! So just open the ****gate for me will you!”

The guard automatically glanced where I was pointing and saw Chris fading into the distance. He gave a shout of surprise as he grabbed up a nightstick and left the guard box to chase after him. I grabbed my head in frustration, banging on the gate as if that would make it budge. What was wrong with these people? Why was he treating me and Chris like some sort of criminal? Had things always been this way and I had just been too blind to notice? And now that I thought about it, why did the schools lock us in anyway? It was like we were prisoners.

I saw Chris coming back around the side of the building, the gate guard yelling right behind him. Plastering myself against the wall so as not to be spotted I waited. Soon enough I heard some scraping and looked around the corner, seeing my brother jumping down off the wall. A second later Chris was on top as well, crouching with his hands between his legs. The guard was yelling and blustering for him to get down but the words were ignored. Chris looked back at the school a moment and stiffened like he had seen a ghost.

When I turned to search the school building through the gate I didn’t see anything out of place. But something had spooked him. Then I heard his voice from the top of the wall.

“Billy. Go home without me. Stay inside all day no matter what. No matter what you see or hear just run straight home.”

“But…!”

“Trust me. Now go.”

Billy began to run down the street. He only made it a few feet before he stopped and turned to look back. I heard shifting rocks as Chris jumped off the wall and the yells from the guard suddenly stopped. A glance through the bars let me just make out the guys feet laying motionless on the ground. Chris ran into the school building like a bat out of hell. I didn’t notice when Billy came up beside me.

“What are you doing here sis?”

I didn’t answer him, simply stared at the front of the school building. A pit growing in my stomach like a black hole. Dread sucked at the very core of my being. Just when I thought I was being overly paranoid the school exploded.

It was like a chain reaction going off. First the outermost windows of the school blew outward on all three floors and then the next set as it worked its way inward. I could hear the screams from here. Screams that were abruptly cut off a second later. With one final heave the top two floors of the school burst outwards, raining rocks, debris and body parts down everywhere.

My mouth opened and closed a few times as my mind tried to accept what it was I was seeing. This couldn’t be happening. This was impossible. I wouldn’t believe it. A child’s hand landed in the yard just on the other side of the fence. Charred and unrecognizable but a finger still twitching. I felt my hand rising to my mouth in horror. I didn’t realize I was already screaming.

“CH---R---I---S!”

“Ouch. Looks like lover boy is dead. I wonder how she will take this. Well I already know of course… but you don’t. Such a tragic end for boy wonder too. I wonder if Richard could get her on the rebound. Oops I better not spoil anything for you. So… uh… yeah… that was a joke by the way. Richard won’t get her on the rebound…”
…..
…..
…..
122111.title: the bewildered damsel

1221111.content:
“NOOOOOOOOOO!”

“Sis… come on we need to get going. I don’t know what is going on but big brother Chris told me to get home and not leave. I think he was right. I have a feeling things are going to get bad really soon.”

I felt his hand tugging on mine and let him lead me away. I couldn’t stop the tears from flowing. He was dead. Blown into little bits. Why had he gone into the school? Why hadn’t he left with Billy?

The world passed me in a blur. It was all just random noises and flashing moments of darkness and light. It was over. Everything was over. Chris wouldn’t be there in the mornings to greet me. Or make witty one liners with his dry sarcastic voice. He wouldn’t be there to play along with my flights of fancy, or make me feel safe when I was scared.

I wouldn’t hear him tell me that he loved me anymore or see him glancing at me sideways when he thought I wasn’t looking. All the normal days were gone in an instant. Destroyed along with the school. He had somehow known all about this. Somehow he knew it was going to happen. He had been telling me goodbye before. Back before he had left me at the church. I had just been too stupid to realize it.

I wanted to tell him I loved him too. I knew that now. Funny how I only realized it after he was dead. I wanted to answer his feelings properly. But I couldn’t now. He’d never get to hear those words. Why had I been so stupid? So blind?

I blinked a few times and realized I was standing in the living room. When had I gotten here? When had we left the school? I needed to go back there. He might still be alive. It was possible. He could have escaped. He wasn’t allowed to be dead until I told him how I felt. Please god, just let him be alive! Let him somehow escape!

I turned to leave the room, fully intending to walk back to the school when my dad stepped in front of door and shook his head.

“It’s best if you stay inside honey. Billy told us what happened and I was out there. It’s not safe right now.”

“But he’s alive! He needs my help!”

“If he is still alive then the police will handle it. If you go out now you will end up getting killed and he wouldn’t want that now would he? There is rioting in the streets and a lot of madness all over town. It probably won’t reach this section though and the military is already enforcing order. I don’t want you to get caught up in it.”

Then what am I supposed to do?”

I heard the lost and pleading tone of my voice but didn’t care. The world was ending. Chris was dead and nothing my dad was saying made much sense. This was Gorgon City, where nothing really bad happened. There was no way there could be rioting. No way Chris could actually be dead. This was like what happened in a dream.

That was it! This was all a dream! I would wake up and none of this will have happened! All I needed to do was pinch myself awake. After all, Chris couldn’t cut off someone’s arm or climb trees without using his hands. He couldn’t do any of the stuff I had seen him do. He would never say the things he had said. Leaving me or Billy alone in a real crises and simply telling us to run home. That wasn’t like him.

I pinched my arm but nothing happened except I felt the sharp pain where I had grabbed. Maybe the arm wasn’t a good spot, maybe my cheek would be better. Still nothing. I had to find someplace more painful. I had to wake up.

My mom touched my arm, shaking her head when I looked at her.

“It’s not a dream sweetie. Doing that will do no good.”

I felt the tears beginning to well up again as she took me in her arms and rocked me back and forth.

“It’s ok sweetie. Maybe he did make it out. If he did I just know he will come running over here straight away. When he does I bet he is going to be really hungry. So let’s set a plate for him at lunch ok? You can cry your eyes out and make yourself look nice so he doesn’t have to worry about you when he comes. You know he will worry if you aren’t your usual self, because that’s just how he is. Now why don’t you help me prepare lunch ok?”

I slowly nodded my head against her chest and let her lead me towards the kitchen. She was right. He would come running as soon as he could. He always came running. He always found me when I was lost. Always knew the right things to say to make me feel better. And right now I was really lost and needed to hear his voice. Even if it was to make fun of me.

“Poor girl. She just can’t accept that he is dead. What is it about you mortals anyway? Whenever someone dies you almost always beg me to give them back to you. Yet ninety percent of the rest of the time you are either cursing my name or don’t believe I exist. It’s not all that easy to bring a person back to life you know. There is a natural order to things. Even I can’t mess with that order easily.”

“What did you think? I would make light of this situation? I’m not that heartless. I can appreciate such somber moments of loss as well. Even if I can’t completely understand it. Losing something or someone precious is always hard to handle. I hope she can get over this soon.”

I blinked and found myself staring at my reflection in the bathroom mirror. How long had I been standing here? How long had the water been running? Slowly I turned the faucet off and looked at my reflection again. My long blond hair seemed to have lost some of its luster and my blue eyes were rimmed red from so much crying. They had lost some of the life in them as well. Was this really what I looked like? I needed to fix this. I couldn’t let Chris see me like this. He would make fun of me for sure.

I ran a comb through my hair, holding it up in a few different positions. Deciding to wear it in a ponytail. He always had liked ponytails. Once that was done I used a bit of make-up and water to clear away the worst of the red around my eyes. When he came for lunch I would waste no time in telling him how I felt. He would like that. But that meant I had to be strong, I couldn’t cry anymore.

After leaving the bathroom I headed for the stairs. While passing Billy’s room I heard muffled sobs through his door. My own eyes began to water again, threatening to undo all the work I had just done. Clenching my fists I walked away. Chris was still alive after all.

Lunchtime drew near and I began to get anxious. What would he say to my confession? Would he kiss me again? Did I want him to kiss me again in front of my family? Would he laugh at how worried I was about him? If he did I would smack him. But that was just like him too. To simply laugh off a serious event like this.

As we sat around the table everyone seemed to be forcing themselves to act cheerful for my sake. I wasn’t worried. I knew he would come. I had set a plate out for him after all. I had piled it with mashed potatoes, some peas, and topped his hamburger steak with mushrooms. He loved mushrooms. It was ready and waiting for him. Now all he had to do was come over.

The doorbell rang just as I was about to put my first forkful of food in my mouth. I dropped it back to my plate as I bounded out of my chair. He was here! Just like my mom said he would be. I knew he wasn’t dead! I could feel my cheeks stretched to their fullest as I yanked open the door. My grin disappearing in an instant when I saw it was old Miss Haubenaker from across the street.

“Chelsea dear! What are you doing home? Shouldn’t you be in school?”

My hand dropped listlessly from the door as I turned to shuffle back to the table. My mom came around the corner and saw who it was while I moved away, all my energy suddenly gone again. I heard the old woman ask to borrow some sugar but I didn’t care. She wasn’t Chris.

Lunchtime passed but still he didn’t show up. I refused to let anyone take his plate off the table. He was going to be hungry when he came and hamburger steak was his favorite. Mom put some cling wrap over it but otherwise left it alone. With a sigh I shuffled into the living room and plopped down on the couch. aimlessly picking up the remote and flicking through the channels.

“At eight fifty three this morning Heronus middle school exploded from an attack made by a terrorist group calling themselves the Inquisition. Police and firefighters have been working tirelessly to clear the wreckage. Of the two hundred and twenty three children that attend this school only twenty two are still alive. Those who did not attend school today for whatever reason were the only ones not killed by the explosion. No other survivors have been found. A copy of the official attendance records for this morning are being pulled off an external server and the families of the victims are being notified as we speak. Stay tuned to GCNS for more info.”

No survivors. Of course there would be no survivors. It was impossible to survive a blast like that. I had been there after all. I knew there was no chance anyone could survive that. I let the remote drop back to the couch as my hands covered my face and I began to cry. The cushions next to me shifted as Billy sat down next to me. I latched on to him just like he latched onto me, our tears mingling together.
1221111.title: Poor Chelsea...

12211111.content:
……

……

“Are you really sure you want to continue? I looked ahead a bit and from here on out its quite heartbreaking. It brings tears to even my eyes. We can go back if you want. I’ll make a small exception for you this time and rewind time to a different point entirely. There is only one place these feelings of hers can end. I really don’t want you to see that.”

“I know. I know. You aren’t going to listen to me like you never listen to me on anything else. I say don’t do it and you do it anyway. I’m never able to change your mind once you decide. Well then let us push onward to see how Chelsea’s story ends.”

“Sweetie? What would you like for dinner?”

“Yeah.”

“I’ll make you anything you want.”

“Yeah.”

“Things seemed to have calmed down outside.”

“Yeah.”

I noted my mother heading off out of the living room again but couldn’t find the energy to care. The TV was just a bunch of flashing lights and noise that didn’t make any sense. I should turn it off. I kept staring at the screen where people were laughing for some reason. What was the point of turning it off? They would still be laughing. What was the point of anything? Chris was dead after all. Flicking a channel, eating, bathing, going to the bathroom, even the simple act of moving wouldn’t change that. So why should I bother doing any of that? Better to just sit here and waste away.

Someone grabbed my hand and tried to pull me up. I resisted. I just wanted to sit here forever. I blinked as the tugging didn’t stop, putting energy into turning my head to see who was pulling on my arm. It was Billy. Why was he trying to get me to move? I should tell him to stop. No. Let him tug, telling him to stop was too much effort.

“Come on sis! Let’s go to the store. We can get some things for dinner.”

Why even reply? How could he be so cheerful? He had seen Chris die the same as I had. It had only happened less than nine hours ago. Had Chris meant so little to him? That he could just forget him so easily?

He stopped tugging on my arm his eyes beginning to well up a bit.

“Come on sis please? I know it hurts. I’m doing my best to keep it together because that’s what he would have done. What would he say to you if he saw you right now? Please get up. Please move. Just a short walk to the store ok? A bit of fresh air, a little exercise to get the blood flowing. For me?”

He stared at me so intently. His eyes soft, reminding me of Chris’ green ones. His lower lip quivered as he began tugging on my arm again. I didn’t want to move. But I got unwillingly to my feet anyway. Because those eyes were so insistent. He steered me by the hand to the door, making me sit down again as he put my shoes on for me. What was the point in shoes? Nothing I stepped on would feel as bad as the emptiness inside.

We were out the door and walking down the street by the time I became aware of my surroundings again. I was useless. Worthless. A coward and a fool. Stupid and blind. There was nothing good about me. If there was he would still be alive. I was just a waste of space. He had known that. That’s why he had left me. Why he hadn’t trusted me. Why I couldn’t save him.

I should just end it all. Just kill myself to make up for it. No one would miss me. No one would mourn the loss of such a useless pile of garbage. They would probably cheer me on. Then I could see Chris again. Even though I didn’t deserve to see him he would still find me in heaven or hell or wherever I ended up. Yes that made sense. I would kill myself.

“ARRRRGGGGGHHHH!”

Someone was running at us with a baseball bat in his hands. He looked crazy. He looked like he was going to hurt us. That was fine. He could smash my head in for me. Save me the trouble of taking my own life. I felt my feet shuffle towards him even as my brother’s hand tried to tug me back. I wasn’t afraid. I could see Chris again soon.

A shadow came hurtling out of nowhere. It looked like a woman but I couldn’t be sure. She caught the man running towards me with a clothesline, dragging him off into the night and around the corner before I could stop her.

NOOOO! Bring him back! Let him kill me! Let him beat me senseless! Please!”

I began to cry in frustration as Billy pulled me after him. I didn’t resist. I would just have to do it myself. I had time. I would find a way. Billy would try to stop me, but he couldn’t watch me all the time. He would look away eventually. Perhaps if I could jump in front of a car. That might work.

But no car crossed my path on the way to the store. I still had time. I had all the time in the world.

Billy led me up and down the few isles of the convenience store, trying to get me interested in buying something. Talking about the newest candy like it mattered. Nothing mattered anymore. Nothing except dying. He tugged me up to the cashier and I wondered if he had a gun behind the counter. Didn’t these kinds of places always have guns? Would he shoot me with it if I made a scene? Could I get it and shoot myself?
